aback: Towards the back or rear; backwards.
abase: To lower, as in condition in life, office, rank, etc., so as to cause pain or hurt feelings; to degrade, to depress, to humble, to humiliate.
abbey: The office or dominion of an abbot or abbess.
abbot: The superior or head of an abbey or monastery.
abhor: To regard with horror or detestation; to shrink back with shuddering from; to feel excessive repugnance toward; to detest to extremity; to loathe.
abide: To endure without yielding; to withstand; await defiantly; to encounter; to persevere.
abled: (in combination) Having a range of physical powers as specified.
abode: To endure without yielding; to withstand; await defiantly; to encounter; to persevere.
abort: A miscarriage; an untimely birth; an abortion.
above: In or to a higher place; higher than; over.
abuse: Improper treatment or usage; application to a wrong or bad purpose; an unjust, corrupt or wrongful practice or custom.
abyss: Hell; the bottomless pit; primeval chaos; a confined subterranean ocean.

acrid: Sharp and harsh, or bitter and not to the taste.
actor: A person who performs, plays a part in a theatrical play or film.
acute: A person who has the acute form of a disorder, such as schizophrenia.
adage: An old saying which has obtained credit by long use
adapt: To make suitable; to make to correspond; to fit or suit

adult: A fully grown human or animal.
affix: That which is affixed; an appendage.
afoot: (predicative) That is on foot, in motion, in action, in progress.
afoul: (principally nautical) In a state of collision or entanglement.

agape: In a state of astonishment, wonder, expectation, or eager attention; as with mouth hanging open.

ahead: In or to the front; in advance; onward.

aloft: At, to, or in the air or sky.
aloof: Reserved and remote; either physically or emotionally distant; standoffish.
alpha: The name of the first letter of the Greek alphabet (Α,  α), followed by beta. In the Latin alphabet it is the predecessor to A.
altar: A table or similar flat-topped structure used for religious rites.
alter: To change the form or structure of.
amass: A large number of things collected or piled together.
amber: Ambergris, the waxy product of the sperm whale.
amble: An unhurried leisurely walk or stroll.

amiss: Fault; wrong; an evil act, a bad deed.

among: Denotes a mingling or intermixing with distinct or separable objects. (See Usage Note at amidst.)
ample: Large; great in size, extent, capacity, or bulk; for example spacious, roomy or widely extended.

anime: An artistic style originating in, and associated with, Japanese animation, and that has also been adopted by a comparatively low number of animated works from other countries.
ankle: The skeletal joint which connects the foot with the leg; the uppermost portion of the foot and lowermost portion of the leg, which contain this skeletal joint.

atone: To make reparation, compensation, amends or satisfaction for an offence, crime, mistake or deficiency.
attic: The space, often unfinished and with sloped walls, directly below the roof in the uppermost part of a house or other building, generally used for storage or habitation.
audio: A sound, or a sound signal
aunty: The sister or sister-in-law of one’s parent.
avail: Effect in achieving a goal or aim; purpose, use (now usually in negative constructions).

aware: Vigilant or on one's guard against danger or difficulty.

basin: A wide bowl for washing, sometimes affixed to a wall
baste: To sew with long or loose stitches, as for temporary use, or in preparation for gathering the fabric.

birch: Any of various trees of the genus Betula, native to countries in the Northern Hemisphere.
birth: The process of childbearing; the beginning of life.
bitty: (often in the plural) bitch, girl, woman, especially one that is promiscuous
black: The colour/color perceived in the absence of light, but also when no light is reflected, but rather absorbed.

burly: (usually of a man) Large, well-built, and muscular.

buxom: Pliant, obedient, tractable (to) (i.e. easily moved or bent, morally).

bylaw: A local custom or law of a settlement or district.
cabal: # A putative, secret organization of individuals gathered for a political purpose.
cabby: A cabdriver; someone who drives a taxi.

cable: (material) A long object used to make a physical connection.
cacao: A tree, Theobroma cacao, whose seed is used to make chocolate.

cause: (often with of, typically of adverse results) The source of, or reason for, an event or action; that which produces or effects a result.

chaos: The unordered state of matter in classical accounts of cosmogony.

charm: An object, act or words believed to have magic power (usually carries a positive connotation).

child: A person who has not yet reached adulthood, whether natural (puberty), cultural (initiation), or legal (majority)

cinch: A simple saddle girth used in Mexico.
circa: Approximately, about, around (typically in relation to time)

civil: Having to do with people and government office as opposed to the military or religion.

claim: A demand of ownership made for something.
clamp: A brace, band, or clasp for strengthening or holding things together.
clang: A loud, ringing sound, like that made by free-hanging metal objects striking each other.
clank: A loud, hard sound of metal hitting metal.
clash: A loud sound, like the crashing together of metal objects.
clasp: A fastener or holder, particularly one that clasps.
class: A group, collection, category or set sharing characteristics or attributes.
clean: Free from dirt, marks, or stains; to remove dirt, marks, or stains from something.

cleft: An opening, fissure, or V-shaped indentation made by or as if by splitting.

clink: The sound of metal on metal, or glass on glass.

clock: An instrument used to measure or keep track of time; a non-portable timepiece.

cloth: A woven fabric such as used in dressing, decorating, cleaning or other practical use.
cloud: A visible mass of condensed water vapor floating in the atmosphere, typically high above the ground.

cluck: The sound made by a hen, especially when brooding, or calling her chicks.

conic: A curve obtained as the intersection of the surface of a cone with a plane; examples include ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas.
copse: A thicket of small trees or shrubs.
coral: A hard substance made of the limestone skeletons of marine polyps.
couch: Couch grass, a species of persistent grass, Elymus repens, usually considered a weed.
cough: A sudden, usually noisy expulsion of air from the lungs, often involuntary.
could: (auxiliary verb, defective) To know how to; to be able to.
count: The act of counting or tallying a quantity.
coupe: An ice cream dessert; the glass it is served in.
court: An enclosed space; a courtyard; an uncovered area shut in by the walls of a building, or by different buildings; also, a space opening from a street and nearly surrounded by houses; a blind alley.
coven: A formal group or assembly of witches.
cover: Something that is placed over or on top of another thing, typically to protect it, conceal it, or close it.
covet: To wish for with eagerness; to desire possession of, often enviously.
covey: A group of 8 to 12 (or more) quail.
cower: To crouch or cringe, or to avoid or shy away from something, in fear.
coyly: In a coy manner, often characterized by shyness, modesty, or flirtatiousness.
crack: A thin and usually jagged space opened in a previously solid material.
cramp: A painful contraction of a muscle which cannot be controlled.
crane: Any bird of the family Gruidae, large birds with long legs and a long neck which is extended during flight.
crank: A bent piece of an axle or shaft, or an attached arm perpendicular, or nearly so, to the end of a shaft or wheel, used to impart a rotation to a wheel or other mechanical device; also used to change circular into reciprocating motion, or reciprocating into circular motion.
crash: A sudden, intense, loud sound, as made for example by cymbals.
crass: Coarse; crude; unrefined or insensitive; lacking discrimination
crate: A large open box or basket, used especially to transport fragile goods.
crave: A formal application to a court to make a particular order.
crawl: The act of moving slowly on hands and knees etc, or with frequent stops.
crazy: An insane or eccentric person; a crackpot.
creak: The sound produced by anything that creaks; a creaking.
cream: The butterfat/milkfat part of milk which rises to the top; this part when separated from the remainder.
credo: A statement of the beliefs or aims that guide someone's actions; a belief system.
creed: That which is believed; accepted doctrine, especially religious doctrine; a particular set of beliefs; any summary of principles or opinions professed or adhered to.
creek: A small inlet or bay, often saltwater, narrower and extending farther into the land than a cove; a recess in the shore of the sea, or of a river; the inner part of a port that is used as a dock for small boats.
creep: To move slowly with the abdomen close to the ground.
creme: A very sugary, fluffy white cream derivative.
crepe: A flat round pancake-like pastry from Lower Brittany, made with wheat.
crept: To move slowly with the abdomen close to the ground.
cress: (plants) A plant of various species, chiefly cruciferous. The leaves have a moderately pungent taste, and are used as a salad and antiscorbutic.
crest: The summit of a hill or mountain ridge.
crick: A painful muscular cramp or spasm of some part of the body, as of the neck or back, making it difficult to move the part affected. (Compare catch.)
crier: One who sheds tears, often due to strong emotions such as sadness, joy, or frustration.
crime: A specific act committed in violation of the law.
crimp: A fastener or a fastening method that secures parts by bending metal around a joint and squeezing it together, often with a tool that adds indentations to capture the parts.
crisp: A thin slice of fried potato eaten as a snack.
croak: A faint, harsh sound made in the throat.
crock: A stoneware or earthenware jar or storage container.
crook: A bend; turn; curve; curvature; a flexure.
cross: A geometrical figure consisting of two straight lines or bars intersecting each other such that at least one of them is bisected by the other.
croup: An infectious illness of the larynx, especially in young children, causing respiratory difficulty.
crowd: A group of people congregated or collected into a close body without order.
crown: A royal, imperial or princely headdress; a diadem.
crude: Any substance in its natural state.
cruel: To spoil or ruin (one's chance of success)
crumb: A small piece which breaks off from baked food (such as cake, biscuit or bread).
crump: The sound of a muffled explosion.
crush: A violent collision or compression; a crash; destruction; ruin.
crust: A more solid, dense or hard layer on a surface or boundary.
cubic: Relating to the volume of a cube or having the shape of a cube.
cumin: The flowering plant Cuminum cyminum, in the family Apiaceae.
curio: A strange and interesting object; something that evokes curiosity.
curly: A person or animal with curly hair.
curry: One of a family of dishes originating from South Asian cuisine, flavoured by a spiced sauce.
curse: A supernatural detriment or hindrance; a bane.
curve: A gentle bend, such as in a road.
cyber: Everything having to do with the Internet considered collectively.
cycle: An interval of space or time in which one set of events or phenomena is completed.
cynic: A person who believes that all people are motivated by selfishness.
daily: Something that is produced, consumed, used, or done every day.
dairy: (also dairy products or dairy produce) Products produced from milk.
daisy: A wild flowering plant Bellis perennis of the Asteraceae family, with a yellow head and white petals
dally: To waste time in trivial activities, or in idleness; to trifle.
dance: A sequence of rhythmic steps or movements usually performed to music, for pleasure or as a form of social interaction.
dandy: A man very concerned about his clothes and his appearance.
datum: (plural: data) A measurement of something on a scale understood by both the recorder (a person or device) and the reader (another person or device). The scale is arbitrarily defined, such as from 1 to 10 by ones, 1 to 100 by 0.1, or simply true or false, on or off, yes, no, or maybe, etc.
dealt: To distribute among a number of recipients, to give out as one’s portion or share.
death: The cessation of life and all associated processes; the end of an organism's existence as an entity independent from its environment and its return to an inert, nonliving state.
debar: To exclude or shut out; to bar.
debit: In bookkeeping, an entry in the left hand column of an account.
debug: The action, or a session, of reviewing source code to find and eliminate errors.
debut: A performer's first performance to the public, in sport, the arts or some other area.
decal: A design or picture produced in order to be transferred to another surface either permanently or temporarily.
decay: The process or result of being gradually decomposed.
decor: The style of decoration of a room or building.
decoy: A person or object meant to lure somebody into danger.
deign: To condescend; to do despite a perceived affront to one's dignity.
deity: A supernatural divine being; a god or goddess.
delay: A period of time before an event occurs; the act of delaying; procrastination; lingering inactivity.
delta: The fourth letter of the modern Greek alphabet Δ, δ.
delve: To dig the ground, especially with a shovel.
demur: Stop; pause; hesitation as to proceeding; suspense of decision or action; scruple.
denim: A textile often made of cotton with a distinct diagonal pattern.
depot: A storage facility, in particular, a warehouse.
depth: The vertical distance below a surface; the degree to which something is deep
derby: Any of several annual horse races.
detox: Detoxification, especially of the body from alcohol or illegal, addictive drugs.
deuce: A card with two pips, one of four in a standard deck of playing cards.
diary: A daily log of experiences, especially those of the writer.
digit: A stage of proficiency or qualification in a course of study, now especially an award bestowed by a university or, in some countries, a college, as a certification of academic achievement. (In the United States, can include secondary schools.)
dingo: Canis lupus dingo, a wild dog native to Australia.
diode: An electronic device that allows current to flow in one direction only; used chiefly as a rectifier.
dirge: A mournful poem or piece of music composed or performed as a memorial to a dead person.
disco: A genre of dance music that was popular in the 1970s, characterized by elements of soul music with a strong Latin-American beat and often accompanied by pulsating lights.
ditch: A trench; a long, shallow indentation, as for irrigation or drainage.
ditto: That which was stated before, the aforesaid, the above, the same, likewise.
diver: Someone who dives, especially as a sport.
dogma: An authoritative principle, belief or statement of opinion, especially one considered to be absolutely true and indisputable, regardless of evidence or without evidence to support it.
dolly: A small platform on wheels used for moving heavy objects.
donut: A deep-fried piece of dough or batter, commonly made in a toroidal or ellipsoidal shape, and mixed with various sweeteners and flavors, sometimes filled with jelly, custard or cream.
doubt: Disbelief or uncertainty (about something); a particular instance of such disbelief or uncertainty.
dough: A thick, malleable substance made by mixing flour with other ingredients such as water, eggs, and/or butter, that is made into a particular form and then baked.
dowel: A pin, or block, of wood or metal, fitting into holes in the abutting portions of two pieces, and being partly in one piece and partly in the other, to keep them in their proper relative position.
downy: Having down, covered with a soft fuzzy coating as of small feathers or hair.
dowry: Payment, such as property or money, paid by the bride's family to the groom or his family at the time of marriage.
draft: A current of air, usually coming into a room or vehicle.
drain: A conduit allowing liquid to flow out of an otherwise contained volume; a plughole (UK)
drama: A composition, normally in prose, telling a story and intended to be represented by actors impersonating the characters and speaking the dialogue
drawl: A way of speaking slowly while lengthening vowel sounds and running words together. Characteristic of some southern US accents, as well as Scots.
dread: Great fear in view of impending evil; fearful apprehension of danger; anticipatory terror.
dream: Imaginary events seen in the mind while sleeping.
dress: An item of clothing (usually worn by a woman or young girl) which both covers the upper part of the body and includes skirts below the waist.
dried: Without water or moisture, said of something that has previously been wet or moist; resulting from the process of drying.
drier: One who, or that which, dries; a desiccative.
drift: (physical) Movement; that which moves or is moved.
drill: A tool used to remove material so as to create a hole, typically by plunging a rotating cutting bit into a stationary workpiece.
drink: To consume (a liquid) through the mouth.
drive: Motivation to do or achieve something; ability coupled with ambition.
droll: A funny person; a buffoon, a wag.
drone: A male ant, bee or wasp, which does not work but can fertilize the queen bee.
droop: Something which is limp or sagging
drove: A number of cattle driven to market or new pastures.
drown: To die from suffocation while immersed in water or other fluid.
druid: One of an order of priests among certain groups of Celts before the adoption of Abrahamic religions.
drunk: To consume (a liquid) through the mouth.
dryer: One who, or that which, dries; a desiccative.
duchy: A dominion or region ruled by a duke or duchess. (A grand duchy may be a self-governing state. A simple duchy tends to be a part of a larger kingdom or empire.)
dully: In a dull manner; without liveliness; without lustre.
dummy: A silent person; a person who does not talk.
dumpy: A short, stout person or animal, especially one of a breed of very short-legged chickens.
duvet: A thick, padded quilt used instead of blankets.
dwarf: Any member of a race of beings from (especially Scandinavian and other Germanic) folklore, usually depicted as having some sort of supernatural powers and being skilled in crafting and metalworking, often as short with long beards, and sometimes as clashing with elves.
dwell: A period of time in which a system or component remains in a given state.
dying: To stop living; to become dead; to undergo death.
eagle: Any of several large carnivorous and carrion-eating birds in the family Accipitridae, having a powerful hooked bill and keen vision.
early: A shift (scheduled work period) that takes place early in the day.
earth: The third planet of the Solar System; the world upon which humans live.
easel: An upright frame, typically on three legs, for displaying or supporting something, such as an artist's canvas.
ebony: A hard, dense, deep black wood from various subtropical and tropical trees, especially of the genus Diospyros.
eclat: A brilliant or successful effect; brilliance of success or effort; splendor; brilliant show; striking effect; glory; renown.
edict: A proclamation of law or other authoritative command.
egret: Any of various wading birds of the genera Egretta or Ardea that includes herons, many of which are white or buff, and several of which develop fine plumes during the breeding season.
eject: To compel (a person or persons) to leave.
eking: The act or process of adding.
elbow: The joint between the upper arm and the forearm.
elder: An older person or an older member, usually a leader, of some community.
elegy: A mournful or plaintive poem; a funeral song; a poem of lamentation.
elfin: An elf; an inhabitant of fairy-land.
elite: A special group or social class of people which have a superior intellectual, social or economic status as, the elite of society.
elope: (of a married person) To run away from home with a paramour.
elude: To evade, or escape from someone or something, especially by using cunning or skill
email: A system for transferring messages from one computer to another, usually through a network.
embed: An embedded reporter or journalist, such as a war reporter assigned to and travelling with a military unit, or a political reporter assigned to follow and report on the campaign of a candidate.
ember: A glowing piece of coal or wood.
empty: (usually plural) A container, especially a bottle, whose contents have been used up, leaving it empty.
endow: To provide with a dower or a dowry.
enema: An injection of fluid into the large intestine by way of the rectum, usually for medical purposes.
enemy: Someone who is hostile to, feels hatred towards, opposes the interests of, or intends injury to someone else.
enjoy: To receive pleasure or satisfaction from something
ennui: A gripping listlessness or melancholia caused by boredom; depression.
enter: The "Enter" key on a computer keyboard.
envoy: A short stanza at the end of a poem, used either to address a person or to comment on the preceding body of the poem.
epoch: A particular period of history, especially one considered noteworthy or remarkable.
epoxy: A thermosetting polyepoxide resin used chiefly in strong adhesives, coatings and laminates; epoxy resin.
equal: A person or thing of equal status to others.
equip: To supply with something necessary in order to carry out a specific action or task; to provide with (e.g. weapons, provisions, munitions, rigging)
erect: Upright; vertical or reaching broadly upwards.
erode: To wear away by abrasion, corrosion or chemical reaction.
error: The state, quality, or condition of being wrong.
erupt: To eject something violently (such as lava or water, as from a volcano or geyser).
essay: (authorship) A written composition of moderate length, exploring a particular issue or subject.
ester: A compound most often formed by the condensation of an alcohol and an acid, with elimination of water, which contains the functional group carbon-oxygen double bond joined via carbon to another oxygen atom.
ether: The substance formerly supposed to fill the upper regions of the atmosphere above the clouds, in particular as a medium breathed by deities.
ethic: A set of principles of right and wrong behaviour guiding, or representative of, a specific culture, society, group, or individual.
ethos: The character or fundamental values of a person, people, culture, or movement.
etude: A short piece of music, designed to give a performer practice in a particular area or skill.
evade: To get away from by cunning; to avoid by dexterity, subterfuge, address, or ingenuity; to elude; to cleverly escape from
every: Used to refer to all the individual members of a set without exception.
evict: To expel (one or more people) from their property; to force (one or more people) to move out.
evoke: To call out; to draw out or bring forth.
exact: To demand and enforce the payment or performance of, sometimes in a forcible or imperious way.
exalt: To honor; to hold in high esteem.
excel: To surpass someone or something; to be better or do better than someone or something.
exile: The state of being banished from one's home or country.
exist: (stative) to be; have existence; have being or reality
extra: Something additional, such as an item above and beyond the ordinary school curriculum, or added to the usual charge on a bill.
exult: To rejoice; to be very happy, especially in triumph.
fable: A fictitious narrative intended to enforce some useful truth or precept, usually with animals, etc. as characters; an apologue. Prototypically, Aesop's Fables.
facet: Any one of the flat surfaces cut into a gem.
fairy: The realm of faerie; enchantment, illusion.
faith: A trust or confidence in the intentions or abilities of a person, object, or ideal from prior empirical evidence.
false: One of two options on a true-or-false test.
farce: A style of humor marked by broad improbabilities with little regard to regularity or method.
fatal: A fatality; an event that leads to death.
fatty: Containing, composed of, or consisting of fat.
fault: A defect; something that detracts from perfection.
fauna: Animals considered as a group; especially those of a particular country, region, time.
favor: A kind or helpful deed; an instance of voluntarily assisting (someone).
feast: A very large meal, often of a ceremonial nature.
feign: To make a false show or pretence of; to counterfeit or simulate.
fella: (chiefly South US) used to address a male
felon: A person who has committed a felony.
femme: A woman, a wife; a young woman or girl.
fence: A thin artificial barrier that separates two pieces of land or a house perimeter.
feral: A domesticated animal that has returned to the wild; an animal, particularly a domesticated animal, living independently of humans.
ferry: A ship used to transport people, smaller vehicles and goods from one port to another, usually on a regular schedule.
fetal: Pertaining to, or connected with, a fetus.
fetch: An act of fetching, of bringing something from a distance.
fetid: The foul-smelling asafoetida plant, or its extracts.
fetus: An unborn or unhatched vertebrate showing signs of the mature animal.
fever: A higher than normal body temperature of a person (or, generally, a mammal), usually caused by disease.
fiber: A single elongated piece of a given material, roughly round in cross-section, often twisted with other fibers to form thread.
ficus: A plant belonging to the genus Ficus, including the rubber plant.
field: A land area free of woodland, cities, and towns; open country.
fiend: A devil or demon; a malignant or diabolical being; an evil spirit.
fifth: The person or thing in the fifth position.
fifty: A banknote or coin with a denomination of 50.
fight: To contend in physical conflict, either singly or in war, battle etc.
filer: A person who sends documents to an official authority, especially a tax authority, giving information or making a request.
filet: A headband; a ribbon or other band used to tie the hair up, or keep a headdress in place, or for decoration.
filmy: Resembling or made of a thin film; gauzy
filth: Dirt; foul matter; that which soils or defiles.
final: A final examination; a test or examination given at the end of a term or class; the test that concludes a class.
finch: Any bird of the family Fringillidae, seed-eating passerine birds, native chiefly to the Northern Hemisphere and usually having a conical beak.
first: The person or thing in the first position.
fishy: A cold-blooded vertebrate animal that lives in water, moving with the help of fins and breathing with gills.
fixer: Agent noun of fix; one who, or that which, fixes.
fjord: A long, narrow, deep inlet between cliffs.
flail: A tool used for threshing, consisting of a long handle with a shorter stick attached with a short piece of chain, thong or similar material.
flair: A natural or innate talent or aptitude.
flake: A loose filmy mass or a thin chiplike layer of anything
flaky: Consisting of flakes or of small, loose masses; lying, or cleaving off, in flakes or layers; flakelike.
flame: The visible part of fire; a stream of burning vapour or gas, emitting light and heat.
flank: The flesh between the last rib and the hip; the side.
flash: A device that produces a short flash of light to help illuminate a scene, mostly for night-time or indoors photography.
flask: A narrow-necked vessel of metal or glass, used for various purposes; as of sheet metal, to carry gunpowder in; or of wrought iron, to contain quicksilver; or of glass, to heat water in, etc.
fleet: A group of vessels or vehicles.
flesh: The soft tissue of the body, especially muscle and fat.
flick: A short, quick movement, especially a brush, sweep, or flip.
flier: That which flies, as a bird or insect.
fling: An act of throwing, often violently.
flint: A hard, fine-grained quartz that fractures conchoidally and generates sparks when struck.
flirt: A sudden jerk; a quick throw or cast; a darting motion
float: A buoyant device used to support something in water or another liquid.
flock: A large number of birds, especially those gathered together for the purpose of migration.
flood: A (usually disastrous) overflow of water from a lake or other body of water due to excessive rainfall or other input of water.
floor: The interior bottom or surface of a house or building; the supporting surface of a room.
flora: Plants considered as a group, especially those of a particular country, region, time, etc.
floss: A thread used to clean the gaps between the teeth.
flour: Powder obtained by grinding or milling cereal grains, especially wheat, or other foodstuffs such as soybeans and potatoes, and used to bake bread, cakes, and pastry.
flout: The act by which something is flouted; violation of a law.
fluff: Anything light, soft or fuzzy, especially fur, hair, feathers.
fluid: Any substance which can flow with relative ease, tends to assume the shape of its container, and obeys Bernoulli's principle; a liquid, gas or plasma.
fluke: A lucky or improbable occurrence, with the implication that the occurrence could not be repeated.
flume: A ravine or gorge, usually one with water running through.
flung: To move (oneself) abruptly or violently; to rush or dash.
flunk: Of a student, to fail a class; to not pass.
flush: A group of birds that have suddenly started up from undergrowth, trees etc.
flute: A woodwind instrument consisting of a tube with a row of holes that produce sound through vibrations caused by air blown across the edge of the holes, often tuned by plugging one or more holes with a finger; the Western concert flute, a transverse side-blown flute of European origin.
flyer: That which flies, as a bird or insect.
foamy: An inexpensive surfboard made of extruded polystyrene foam
focal: Belonging to, concerning, or located at a focus
focus: A point at which reflected or refracted rays of light converge.
foggy: Obscured by mist or fog; unclear; hazy
folio: A leaf of a book or manuscript
foray: A sudden or irregular incursion in border warfare; hence, any irregular incursion for war or spoils; a raid.
force: Strength or energy of body or mind; active power; vigour; might; capacity of exercising an influence or producing an effect.
forge: Furnace or hearth where metals are heated prior to hammering them into shape.
forgo: To let pass, to leave alone, to let go.
forth: Forward in time, place or degree.
forty: A bottle of beer containing forty fluid ounces.
found: To encounter or discover by accident; to happen upon.
foyer: A lobby, corridor, or waiting room, used in a hotel, theater, etc.
frail: A basket made of rushes, used chiefly to hold figs and raisins.
frame: The structural elements of a building or other constructed object.
frank: Free postage, a right exercised by governments (usually with definite article).
fraud: The crime of stealing or otherwise illegally obtaining money by use of deception tactics.
freed: To make free; set at liberty; release.
fresh: A rush of water, along a river or onto the land; a flood.
friar: A member of a mendicant Christian order such as the Augustinians, Carmelites (white friars), Franciscans (grey friars) or the Dominicans (black friars).
frill: A strip of pleated fabric or paper used as decoration or trim.
frisk: A frolic; a fit of wanton gaiety; a gambol: a little playful skip or leap.
frock: A dress, a piece of clothing for a female, which consists of a skirt and a cover for the upper body.
frond: The leaf of a fern, especially a compound leaf.
front: The foremost side of something or the end that faces the direction it normally moves.
frost: A cover of minute ice crystals on objects that are exposed to the air. Frost is formed by the same process as dew, except that the temperature of the frosted object is below freezing.
froth: An aggregation of bubbles, as on an agitated liquid or at the mouth of a hard-driven horse; foam; spume.
frown: A facial expression in which the eyebrows are brought together, and the forehead is wrinkled, usually indicating displeasure, sadness or worry, or less often confusion or concentration.
froze: Especially of a liquid, to become solid due to low temperature.
fruit: (often in the plural) In general, a product of plant growth useful to man or animals.
fudge: A type of very sweet candy or confection, usually made from sugar, butter, and milk or cream. Often used in the US synonymously with chocolate fudge.
fugue: A contrapuntal piece of music wherein a particular melody is played in a number of voices, each voice introduced in turn by playing the melody.
fully: In a full manner; without lack or defect.
fungi: Any member of the kingdom Fungi; a eukaryotic organism typically having chitin cell walls but no chlorophyll or plastids. Fungi may be unicellular or multicellular.
furry: An animal character with human-like characteristics; most commonly refers to such characters created by members of the furry subculture.
fussy: Anxious or particular about petty details.
fuzzy: (often in the plural) A very small piece of plush material.
gaffe: A foolish and embarrassing error, especially one made in public.
gamer: A person who plays any kind of game.
gamma: The third letter of the Greek alphabet (Γ, γ), preceded by beta (Β, β) and followed by delta, (Δ, δ).
gassy: Having the nature of, or containing, gas.
gaudy: One of the large beads in the rosary at which the paternoster is recited.
gauge: A measure; a standard of measure; an instrument to determine dimensions, distance, or capacity; a standard
gauze: A thin fabric with a loose, open weave.
gayly: In a merry, lively, or joyous manner, or in a bright or showy way.
gazer: A person who looks at something or someone for a long time, often in admiration or wonder.
gecko: Any lizard of the family Gekkonidae. They are small, carnivorous, mostly nocturnal animals with large eyes and adhesive toes enabling them to climb on vertical and upside-down surfaces.
geeky: Resembling or characteristic of a geek.
geese: Any of various grazing waterfowl of the family Anatidae, which have feathers and webbed feet and are capable of flying, swimming, and walking on land, and which are bigger than ducks.
genie: A jinn, a being descended from the jann, normally invisible to the human eye, but who may also appear in animal or human form.
genre: A kind; a stylistic category or sort, especially of literature or other artworks.
ghost: The spirit; the soul of man.
ghoul: (Muslim demonology) A demon said to feed on corpses.
giant: A mythical human of very great size.
gipsy: (sometimes offensive) A member of the Romani people, or one of the sub-groups (Roma, Sinti, Romanichal, etc).
girth: A band passed under the belly of an animal, which holds a saddle or a harness saddle in place.
giver: One who gives; a donor or contributor.
glade: An open passage through a wood; a grassy open or cleared space in a forest.
gland: An organ that synthesizes a substance, such as hormones or breast milk, and releases it, often into the bloodstream (endocrine gland) or into cavities inside the body or its outer surface (exocrine gland).
glaze: The vitreous coating of pottery or porcelain; anything used as a coating or color in glazing. See glaze (transitive verb).
gleam: A small or indistinct shaft or stream of light.
gloat: An act or instance of gloating.
glory: Great or overwhelming beauty or splendour.
glove: An item of clothing other than a mitten, covering all or part of the hand and fingers, but usually allowing independent movement of the fingers.
glyph: A figure carved in relief or incised, especially representing a sound, word, or idea.
gnash: A sudden snapping of the teeth.
gnome: A brief reflection or maxim; a pithy saying.
godly: Of or pertaining to a god
golem: A humanoid creature made from clay, animated by magic.
gonad: A sex organ that produces gametes; specifically, a testicle or ovary.
goner: Someone (or something) doomed; a hopeless case.
goody: A good character in a story, often a hero.
goose: Any of various grazing waterfowl of the family Anatidae, which have feathers and webbed feet and are capable of flying, swimming, and walking on land, and which are bigger than ducks.
gorge: A narrow cleft with steep, rocky walls, especially one through which a stream runs.
gourd: Any of the trailing or climbing vines producing fruit with a hard rind or shell, from the genera Lagenaria and Cucurbita (in Cucurbitaceae).
graft: A small shoot or scion of a tree inserted in another tree, the stock of which is to support and nourish it. The two unite and become one tree, but the graft determines the kind of fruit.
grain: The harvested seeds of various grass food crops eg: wheat, corn, barley.
grand: (plural "grand") A thousand of some unit of currency, such as dollars or pounds. (Compare G.)
grant: The act of granting; a bestowing or conferring; concession; allowance; permission.
grape: A small, round, smooth-skinned edible fruit, usually purple, red, or green, that grows in bunches on vines of genus Vitis.
graph: (applied mathematics) A data chart (graphical representation of data) intended to illustrate the relationship between a set (or sets) of numbers (quantities, measurements or indicative numbers) and a reference set, whose elements are indexed to those of the former set(s) and may or may not be numbers.
grass: Any plant of the family Poaceae, characterized by leaves that arise from nodes in the stem and leaf bases that wrap around the stem, especially those grown as ground cover rather than for grain.
grate: A horizontal metal grill through which water, ash, or small objects can fall, while larger objects cannot
grave: An excavation in the earth as a place of burial
gravy: A thick sauce made from the fat or juices that come out from meat or vegetables as they are being cooked.
graze: The act of grazing; a scratching or injuring lightly on passing.
great: A person of major significance, accomplishment or acclaim.
greed: A selfish or excessive desire for more than is needed or deserved, especially of money, wealth, food, or other possessions.
greet: To welcome in a friendly manner, either in person or through another means e.g. writing or over the phone/internet
grill: A grating; a grid of wire or a sheet of material with a pattern of holes or slots, usually used to protect something while allowing the passage of air and liquids. Typical uses: to allow air through a fan while preventing fingers or objects from passing; to allow people to talk to somebody, while preventing attack.
grime: Dirt, grease, soot, etc. that is ingrained and difficult to remove.
grind: The act of reducing to powder, or of sharpening, by friction.
gripe: A complaint, often a petty or trivial one.
groan: A low, mournful sound uttered in pain or grief.
groin: The crease or depression of the human body at the junction of the trunk and the thigh, together with the surrounding region.
groom: A man who is about to marry.
grope: An act of groping, especially sexually.
group: A number of things or persons being in some relation to one another.
grout: A thin mortar used to fill the gaps between tiles and cavities in masonry.
growl: A deep, rumbling, threatening sound made in the throat by an animal.
grown: To become larger, to increase in magnitude.
gruel: A thin, watery porridge, formerly eaten primarily by the poor and the ill.
grunt: A short snorting sound, often to show disapproval, or used as a reply when one is reluctant to speak.
guard: A person who, or thing that, protects or watches over something.
guava: A tropical tree or shrub of the myrtle family, Psidium guajava.
guess: To reach a partly (or totally) unqualified conclusion.
guest: A recipient of hospitality, specifically someone staying by invitation at the house of another.
guide: Someone who guides, especially someone hired to show people around a place or an institution and offer information and explanation.
guild: A group or association mainly of tradespeople made up of merchants, craftspeople, or artisans for mutual aid, particularly in the Middle Ages.
guile: Astuteness often marked by a certain sense of cunning or artful deception.
guise: Customary way of speaking or acting; fashion, manner, practice (often used formerly in such phrases as "at his own guise"; that is, in his own fashion, to suit himself.)
gulch: A ravine-like or deep V-shaped valley, often eroded by flash floods; shallower than a canyon and deeper than a gully.
gully: A trench, ravine or narrow channel which was worn by water flow, especially on a hillside.
gumbo: A soup or stew made with okra.
gummy: A sheep that is losing or has lost its teeth.
guppy: A tiny freshwater fish, Poecilia reticulata, popular in home aquariums, that usually has a plain body and black or dark blue tail for the females and a more colorful tail for the males.
gusty: (of wind) Blowing in gusts; blustery; tempestuous.
gypsy: (sometimes offensive) A member of the Romani people, or one of the sub-groups (Roma, Sinti, Romanichal, etc).
habit: An action performed on a regular basis.
hairy: Of a person, having a lot of hair on the body.
halve: To reduce to half the original amount.
happy: A happy event, thing, person, etc.
hardy: (usually in the plural) Anything, especially a plant, that is hardy.
harem: The private part of an Arab household, traditionally forbidden to male strangers.
harpy: A fabulous winged monster, ravenous and filthy, having the face of a woman and the body of a vulture.
hasty: Acting in haste; being too hurried or quick
hatch: A horizontal door in a floor or ceiling.
haunt: A place at which one is regularly found; a habitation or hangout.
haven: A harbour or anchorage protected from the sea.
hazel: A tree or shrub of the genus Corylus, bearing edible nuts called hazelnuts or filberts.
heard: (stative) To perceive sounds through the ear.
heart: A muscular organ that pumps blood through the body, traditionally thought to be the seat of emotion.
heath: A tract of level uncultivated land with sandy soil and scrubby vegetation; heathland.
heave: An effort to raise something, such as a weight or one's own body, or to move something heavy.
heavy: A villain or bad guy; the one responsible for evil or aggressive acts.
hedge: A thicket of bushes or other shrubbery, especially one planted as a fence between two portions of land, or to separate the parts of a garden.
heist: A robbery or burglary, especially from an institution such as a bank or museum.
helix: A curve on the surface of a cylinder or cone such that its angle to a plane perpendicular to the axis is constant; the three-dimensional curve seen in a screw or a spiral staircase.
hence: From here, from this place, away
heron: A long-legged, long-necked wading bird of the family Ardeidae.
hilly: (of a landscape) Abundant in hills; having many hills.
hinge: A jointed or flexible device that allows the pivoting of a door etc.
hippo: A large, semi-aquatic, herbivorous (plant-eating) African mammal (Hippopotamus amphibius)
hippy: (1950s slang) A teenager who imitated the beatniks.
hobby: An activity that one enjoys doing in one's spare time.
hoist: A hoisting device, such as pulley or crane.
holly: Any of various shrubs or (mostly) small trees, of the genus Ilex, either evergreen or deciduous, used as decoration especially at Christmas.
homer: Various former units of volume, particularly:
honey: A viscous, sweet fluid produced from plant nectar by bees. Often used to sweeten tea or to spread on baked goods.
honor: Recognition of importance or value; respect; veneration (of someone, usually for being morally upright or successful)
horde: A wandering troop or gang; especially, a clan or tribe of a nomadic people (originally Tatars) migrating from place to place for the sake of pasturage, plunder, etc.; a predatory multitude.
horny: Hard or bony, like an animal's horn.
horse: Any of several animals related to Equus ferus caballus.
hotel: A large town house or mansion; a grand private residence, especially in France.
hound: A dog, particularly a breed with a good sense of smell developed for hunting other animals.
house: A structure built or serving as an abode of human beings.
hovel: An open shed for sheltering cattle, or protecting produce, etc., from the weather.
hover: To remain in one place in the air
howdy: A friendly greeting, often associated with the American West.
human: A member of the species Homo sapiens, characterized by higher cognitive abilities and the use of complex language.
humid: Containing perceptible moisture (usually describing air or atmosphere); damp; moist; somewhat wet or watery.
humor: The quality of being amusing, comical, funny.
humph: To utter "humph!" in doubt or disapproval.
humus: A large group of natural organic compounds, found in the soil, formed from the chemical and biological decomposition of plant and animal residues and from the synthetic activity of microorganisms
hutch: A cage for keeping rabbits, guinea pigs, etc.
hydro: Relating to water or its use, especially in generating electricity through hydropower.
hyena: Any of the medium-sized to large feliform carnivores of the subfamily Hyaeninae (genera Hyaena and Crocuta), native to Africa and Asia and noted for the sound similar to laughter which they can make if excited.
hymen: A membrane which completely or partially occludes the vaginal opening in human females.
icily: In an unfriendly way that shows no emotion.
icing: A sweet glaze made primarily of sugar and often flavored, typically used for baked goods; frosting.
ideal: A perfect standard of beauty, intellect etc., or a standard of excellence to aim at.
idiom: A manner of speaking, a mode of expression peculiar to a language, person, or group of people.
idiot: A person of low general intelligence.
idler: One who idles; one who spends his or her time in inaction.
idyll: Any poem or short written piece composed in the style of Theocritus' short pastoral poems, the Idylls.
igloo: A dome-shaped Inuit shelter, constructed of blocks cut from snow.
iliac: Relating to the ilium, the uppermost and largest part of the hip bone.
image: An optical or other representation of a real object; a graphic; a picture.
imbue: To wet or stain an object completely with some physical quality.
impel: To urge a person; to press on; to incite to action or motion via intrinsic motivation.
imply: (of a proposition) to have as a necessary consequence
inane: That which is void or empty.
inbox: A container in which papers to be dealt with are put.
incur: To bring upon oneself or become subject to something, especially something unwelcome or unpleasant.
index: A list of items, often in alphabetical order, with references to the places where they occur.
inert: Lacking the ability or strength to move; chemically inactive.
infer: To deduce or conclude information from evidence and reasoning rather than from explicit statements.
ingot: A block of metal, typically oblong in shape, that is cast in a mold and used for storage or further processing.
inlay: A decorative technique where a material is set into the surface of an object to form a design.
inlet: A small arm of the sea, a lake, or a river.
inner: Situated inside or further in; internal.
input: The act of putting in; the information or material that is put in.
inter: To place a dead body in a grave or tomb; to bury.
intro: A short introduction to a piece of music, a book, or another work.
ionic: Relating to, composed of, or using ions.
irony: A statement that, when taken in context, may actually mean something different from, or the opposite of, what is written literally; the use of words expressing something other than their literal intention, often in a humorous context.
issue: The action or an instance of flowing or coming out, an outflow, particularly:
itchy: Having or creating an itch, causing a person or animal to tend to want to scratch.
ivory: The hard white form of dentin which forms the tusks of elephants, walruses and other animals.
jelly: An explosive mixture of nitroglycerine and nitrate absorbed onto a base of wood pulp.
jetty: A structure of wood or stone extended into the sea to influence the current or tide, or to protect a harbor or beach.
jewel: A precious or semi-precious stone; gem, gemstone.
jiffy: A very short, unspecified length of time.
joint: The point where two components of a structure join, but are still able to rotate.
joist: A piece of timber laid horizontally, or nearly so, to which the planks of the floor, or the laths or furring strips of a ceiling, are nailed.
joust: A tilting match: a mock combat between two mounted knights or men-at-arms using lances in the lists or enclosed field.
judge: A public official whose duty it is to administer the law, especially by presiding over trials and rendering judgments; a justice.
juice: A liquid from a plant, especially fruit.
jumbo: An especially large or powerful person, animal, or thing.
junta: A council, convention, tribunal or assembly; especially, the grand council of state in Spain.
junto: A group of men assembled for some common purpose; a club, or cabal.
kappa: The tenth letter of the Greek alphabet.
karma: The sum total of a person's actions, which determine the person's next incarnation in samsara, the cycle of death and rebirth.
kayak: A type of small boat, covered over by a surface deck, powered by the occupant or occupants using a double-bladed paddle in a sitting position, from a hole in the surface deck
kebab: A dish of pieces of meat, fish, or vegetables roasted on a skewer or spit, especially a doner kebab.
khaki: A dull, yellowish-brown colour, the colour of dust.
kinky: Full of kinks; liable to kink or curl.
kiosk: A small enclosed structure, often freestanding, open on one side or with a window, used as a booth to sell newspapers, cigarettes, etc.
knack: A readiness in performance; aptness at doing something.
kneed: To strike or hit with the knee.
kneel: To rest on one or both knees.
knelt: Past tense of kneel; to have rested on one or both knees.
knife: A tool or utensil with a blade and handle, used for cutting or as a weapon.
knock: To strike a surface noisily to attract attention.
knoll: A small, rounded hill or mound.
known: To perceive the truth or factuality of; to be certain of or that.
koala: A tree-dwelling marsupial, Phascolarctos cinereus, that resembles a small bear with a broad head, large ears and sharp claws, mainly found in eastern Australia.
krill: Any of several small marine crustacean species of plankton in the order Euphausiacea in the class Malacostraca.
label: A small ticket or sign giving information about something to which it is attached or intended to be attached.
labor: Effort expended on a particular task; toil, work.
laden: To fill or load (related to cargo or a shipment).
ladle: A deep-bowled spoon with a long, usually curved, handle.
lager: A type of beer, brewed using a bottom-fermenting yeast.
lance: A weapon of war, consisting of a long shaft or handle and a steel blade or head; a spear carried by horsemen.
lanky: Tall, slim, and rather ungraceful or awkward.
lapel: Each of the two triangular pieces of cloth on the front of a jacket or coat that are folded back below the throat, leaving a triangular opening between.
large: An old musical note, equal to two longas, four breves, or eight semibreves.
larva: An early stage of growth for some insects and amphibians, in which after hatching from their egg, insects are wingless and resemble a caterpillar or grub, and amphibians lack limbs and resemble fish.
lasso: A long rope with a sliding loop on one end, generally used in ranching to catch cattle and horses.
latch: To close or lock as if with a latch.
later: Near the end of a period of time.
latte: A drink of coffee made from espresso and steamed milk, generally topped with foam.
laugh: An expression of mirth particular to the human species; the sound heard in laughing; laughter.
layer: A single thickness of some material covering a surface.
leach: A quantity of wood ashes, through which water passes, and thus imbibes the alkali.
leant: To incline, deviate, or bend, from a vertical position; to be in a position thus inclining or deviating.
leash: A strap, cord or rope with which to restrain an animal, often a dog.
least: Something of the smallest possible extent; an indivisible unit.
leave: To have a consequence or remnant.
ledge: A shelf on which articles may be laid; also, that which resembles such a shelf in form or use, as a projecting ridge or part, or a molding or edge in joinery.
leech: An aquatic blood-sucking annelid of class Hirudinea, especially Hirudo medicinalis.
leery: Cautious, suspicious, wary, hesitant, or nervous about something; having reservations or concerns.
legal: The legal department of a company.
leggy: (chiefly of a woman) Having long, attractive legs; long-legged.
lemur: Any strepsirrhine primate of the infraorder Lemuriformes, superfamily Lemuroidea, native only to Madagascar and some surrounding islands.
level: A tool for finding whether a surface is level, or for creating a horizontal or vertical line of reference.
lever: (except in generalized senses below) A crowbar.
libel: A written or pictorial false statement which unjustly seeks to damage someone's reputation.
liege: A free and independent person; specifically, a lord paramount; a sovereign.
light: Visible electromagnetic radiation. The human eye can typically detect radiation (light) in the wavelength range of about 400 to 750 nanometers. Nearby shorter and longer wavelength ranges, although not visible, are commonly called ultraviolet and infrared light.
liken: (followed by to or unto) To compare; to state that (something) is like (something else).
lilac: A large shrub of the genus Syringa, especially Syringa vulgaris, bearing white, pale-pink or purple flowers.
limbo: (Roman Catholic theology, since circa 400 A.D.) The place where innocent souls exist temporarily until they can enter heaven, notably those of the saints who died before the advent of Christ (limbus patruum) and those of unbaptized but innocent children (limbus infantum).
limit: A restriction; a bound beyond which one may not go.
linen: Thread or cloth made from flax fiber.
liner: Someone who fits a lining to something.
lingo: Language, especially language peculiar to a particular group, field, or region; jargon or a dialect.
lipid: Any of a group of organic compounds including the fats, oils, waxes, sterols, and triglycerides. Lipids are characterized by being insoluble in water, and account for most of the fat present in the human body.
liver: A large organ in the body that stores and metabolizes nutrients, destroys toxins and produces bile. It is responsible for thousands of biochemical reactions.
llama: A South American mammal of the camel family, Lama glama, used as a domestic beast of burden and a source of wool and meat.
loamy: Consisting of loam; partaking of the nature of loam; resembling loam.
lobby: An entryway or reception area; vestibule; passageway; corridor.
local: A person who lives near a given place.
locus: A place or locality, especially a centre of activity or the scene of a crime.
lodge: A building for recreational use such as a hunting lodge or a summer cabin.
lofty: High, tall, having great height or stature
logic: A method of human thought that involves thinking in a linear, step-by-step manner about how a problem can be solved. Logic is the basis of many principles including the scientific method.
login: A combination of a user's identification and password used to enter a computer, program, network, etc.
lorry: A motor vehicle for transporting goods, and in some cases people; a truck.
loser: A person who loses; one who fails to win or thrive.
louse: A small parasitic wingless insect of the order Psocodea.
lousy: Remarkably bad; of poor quality, dirty, or underhanded; mean, contemptible.
lover: One who loves and cares for another person in a romantic way; a sweetheart, love, soulmate, boyfriend, girlfriend or spouse.
lower: Situated close to, or even below, the ground or another normal reference plane; not high or lofty.
lowly: Not high; not elevated in place; low.
loyal: Having or demonstrating undivided and constant support for someone or something.
lucky: (of people) Favoured by luck; fortunate; having good success or good fortune
lumen: In the International System of Units, the derived unit of luminous flux; the light that is emitted in a solid angle of one steradian from a source of one candela. Symbol: lm.
lunar: The middle bone of the proximal series of the carpus in the wrist, which is shaped like a half-moon.
lunch: A light meal usually eaten around midday, notably when not as main meal of the day.
lunge: A sudden forward movement, especially with a sword.
lupus: Any of a number of autoimmune diseases, the most common of which is systemic lupus erythematosus.
lusty: Exhibiting lust (in the obsolete sense meaning "vigor"); strong, healthy, robust; vigorous; full of sap or vitality.
lying: To rest in a horizontal position on a surface.
macaw: Any of various parrots of the genera Ara, Anodorhynchus, Cyanopsitta, Orthopsittaca, Primolius and Diopsittaca of Central and South America, including the largest parrots and characterized by long sabre-shaped tails, curved powerful bills, and usually brilliant plumage.
macho: A macho person; a person who tends to display masculine characteristics, such as domineering, fierceness, and bravado.
macro: Very large in scope or scale.
madam: A polite form of address for a woman or lady.
madly: In a mad manner; without reason or understanding; wildly.
mafia: A hierarchically structured secret organisation engaged in illegal activities like distribution of narcotics, gambling and extortion.
magic: The application of rituals or actions, especially those based on occult knowledge, to subdue or manipulate natural or supernatural beings and forces in order to have some benefit from them
magma: The molten matter within the earth, the source of the material of lava flows, dikes of eruptive rocks, etc.
maize: Corn; a type of grain of the species Zea mays.
major: A military rank between captain and lieutenant colonel.
maker: Someone who makes; a person or thing that makes or produces something.
mamma: The milk-secreting organ of female humans and other mammals which includes the mammary gland and the nipple or teat; a breast; an udder. (plural: mammae)
mange: A skin disease of mammals caused by parasitic mites (Sarcoptes spp., Demodecidae spp.).
mango: A tropical Asian fruit tree, Mangifera indica.
mania: Violent derangement of mind; madness; insanity.
manic: Of or pertaining to someone who exhibits mania or craziness; wicked.
manly: Having the characteristics of a man.
maple: A tree of the Acer genus, characterised by its usually palmate leaves and winged seeds.
march: A formal, rhythmic way of walking, used especially by soldiers, bands and in ceremonies.
marry: To enter into the conjugal or connubial state; to take a husband or a wife.
marsh: An area of low, wet land, often with tall grass.
mason: A bricklayer, one whose occupation is to build with stone or brick
match: A competitive sporting event such as a boxing meet, a baseball game, or a cricket match.
matey: The conclusive victory in a game of chess that occurs when an opponent's king is threatened with unavoidable capture.
maxim: A self-evident axiom or premise; a pithy expression of a general principle or rule.
mayor: The chief executive of the municipal government of a city, borough, &c., formerly usually appointed as a caretaker by European royal courts but now usually appointed or elected locally.
meaty: Of, relating to, or containing meat.
medal: A stamped metal disc used as a personal ornament, a charm, or a religious object.
media: The middle layer of the wall of a blood vessel or lymph vessel which is composed of connective and muscular tissue.
melee: A battle fought at close range; hand-to-hand combat; brawling.
melon: Any of various plants of the family Cucurbitaceae grown for food, generally not including the cucumber.
mercy: Relenting; forbearance to cause or allow harm to another.
merge: The joining together of multiple sources.
merit: A claim to commendation or a reward.
merry: Jolly and full of high spirits.
metal: (heading) Chemical elements or alloys, and the mines where their ores come from.
meter: (always meter) A device that measures things.
midge: Any of various small two-winged flies, for example, from the family Chironomidae or non-biting midges, the family Chaoboridae or phantom midges, and the family Ceratopogonidae or biting midges, all belonging to the order Diptera
midst: A place in the middle of something; may be used of a literal or metaphorical location.
might: Power, strength, force or influence held by a person or group.
milky: Resembling milk in color, consistency, smell, etc.; consisting of milk.
mimic: A person who practices mimicry, or mime.
miner: A person who works in a mine.
minim: A half note, drawn as a semibreve with a stem.
minor: A person who is below the age of majority, consent, criminal responsibility or other adult responsibilities and accountabilities.
minty: Having the taste or smell of mint, a herb with a strong, fresh flavor.
mirth: The emotion usually following humour and accompanied by laughter; merriment; jollity; gaiety.
miser: A person who hoards money rather than spending it; one who is cheap or extremely parsimonious.
missy: A young female, or miss; as a term of mild disparagement, typically used jokingly or rebukingly.
mocha: A coffee drink with chocolate syrup added, or a serving thereof; a caffè mocha.
model: A person who serves as a subject for artwork or fashion, usually in the medium of photography but also for painting or drawing.
modem: A device that encodes digital computer signals into analog/analogue telephone signals and vice versa and allows computers to communicate over a phone line.
mogul: A rich or powerful person; a magnate.
molar: A back tooth having a broad surface used for grinding one's food.
money: A legally or socially binding conceptual contract of entitlement to wealth, void of intrinsic value, payable for all debts and taxes, and regulated in supply.
month: A period into which a year is divided, historically based on the phases of the moon.
moody: Given to sudden or frequent changes of mind; temperamental.
moose: The largest member of the deer family (Alces americanus, sometimes included in Alces alces), of which the male has very large, palmate antlers.
moral: (of a narrative) The ethical significance or practical lesson.
moron: A stupid person; an idiot; a fool.
morph: (grammar) A physical form representing some morpheme in language. It is a recurrent distinctive sound or sequence of sounds.
motel: A type of hotel or lodging establishment, often located near a major highway, which typically features a series of rooms the entrances of which are immediately adjacent to a parking lot to facilitate convenient access to automobiles parked there.
motif: A recurring or dominant element; a theme.
motor: A machine or device that converts other energy forms into mechanical energy, or imparts motion.
motto: A sentence, phrase, or word, forming part of an heraldic achievement.
moult: The process of shedding or losing a covering of fur, feathers or skin etc.
mound: An artificial hill or elevation of earth; a raised bank; an embankment thrown up for defense
mouse: Any small rodent of the genus Mus.
mouth: The opening of a creature through which food is ingested.
mover: Someone who or something that moves.
movie: A recorded sequence of images displayed on a screen at a rate sufficiently fast to create the appearance of motion.
mower: A lawnmower, a machine used to cut grass.
mucus: A slippery secretion from the lining of the mucous membranes.
mulch: Any material used to cover the top layer of soil to protect, insulate, or decorate it, or to discourage weeds or retain moisture.
mummy: An embalmed human or animal corpse wrapped in linen bandages for burial, especially as practised by the ancient Egyptians and some Native American tribes.
munch: A location or restaurant where good eating can be expected.
mural: A large painting, usually drawn on a wall.
murky: Hard to see through, as a fog or mist.
mushy: Resembling or having the consistency of mush; semiliquid, pasty, or granular.
music: A series of sounds organized in time, employing melody, harmony, tempo etc. usually to convey a mood.
myrrh: A red-brown resinous material, the dried sap of a tree of the species Commiphora myrrha.
nadir: The point of the celestial sphere, directly opposite the zenith; inferior pole of the horizon; point of the celestial sphere directly under the place of observation.
nasal: A medicine that operates through the nose; an errhine.
naval: Of or relating to a navy.
navel: The indentation or bump remaining in the abdomen of mammals where the umbilical cord was attached before birth.
nerdy: (of a person) Being or like a nerd.
nerve: A bundle of neurons with their connective tissue sheaths, blood vessels and lymphatics.
never: At no time; on no occasion; in no circumstance.
newly: Very recently; in the immediate past.
niche: A cavity, hollow, or recess, generally within the thickness of a wall, for a statue, bust, or other erect ornament. Hence, any similar position, literal or figurative.
niece: A daughter of one’s sibling, brother-in-law, or sister-in-law; either the daughter of one's brother ("fraternal niece"), or of one's sister ("sororal niece").
night: The period between sunset and sunrise, when a location faces far away from the sun, thus when the sky is dark.
ninja: A person skilled in the Japanese art of ninjutsu.
ninth: The person or thing in the ninth position.
noble: An aristocrat; one of aristocratic blood.
noise: Various sounds, usually unwanted or unpleasant.
noisy: Making a noise, especially a loud unpleasant sound
nomad: A member of a society or class who herd animals from pasture to pasture with no fixed home.
noose: An adjustable loop of rope, such as the one placed around the neck in hangings, or the one at the end of a lasso.
north: One of the four major compass points, specifically 0°, directed toward the North Pole, and conventionally upwards on a map, abbreviated as N.
nosey: A look at something to satisfy one's curiosity.
novel: Newly made, formed or evolved; having no precedent; of recent origin; new.
nylon: Originally, the DuPont company trade name for polyamide, a copolymer whose molecules consist of alternating diamine and dicarboxylic acid monomers bonded together; now generically used for this type of polymer.
nymph: (Greek, Roman) Any female nature spirit associated with water, forests, grotto, wind, etc.
oaken: Made from the wood of the oak tree. Also in metaphorical uses, suggesting robustness.
obese: Extremely overweight, especially: weighing more than 20% (for men) or 25% (for women) over their ideal weight determined by height and build; or, having a body mass index over 30 kg/m2.
ocean: One of the large bodies of water separating the continents.
octal: The number system that uses the eight digits 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7.
octet: A group or set of eight of something.
odder: Differing from what is usual, ordinary or expected.
oddly: In a peculiar manner; strangely; unusually.
offal: The internal organs of an animal, used as animal food.
offer: A proposal that has been made.
olden: From or relating to a previous era.
older: Of an object, concept, relationship, etc., having existed for a relatively long period of time.
olive: A tree, Olea europaea, cultivated since ancient times in the Mediterranean for its fruit and the oil obtained from it.
ombre: A large Mediterranean food fish Umbrina cirrosa
omega: The twenty-fourth letter of the Classical and the Modern Greek alphabet, and the twenty-eighth letter of the Old and the Ancient Greek alphabet, i.e. the last letter of every Greek alphabet. Uppercase version: Ω; lowercase: ω.
onion: A monocotyledonous plant (Allium cepa), allied to garlic, used as vegetable and spice.
onset: An attack; an assault especially of an army.
opera: A theatrical work, combining drama, music, song and sometimes dance.
opine: To have or express an opinion; to state as an opinion; to suppose, consider (that).
opium: A yellow-brown, addictive narcotic drug obtained from the dried juice of unripe pods of the opium poppy, Papaver somniferum, and containing alkaloids such as morphine, codeine, and papaverine.
orbit: A circular or elliptical path of one object around another object, particularly in astronomy and space travel.
organ: A larger part of an organism, composed of tissues that perform similar functions.
other: An other, another (person, etc), more often rendered as another.
otter: An aquatic or marine carnivorous mammal in the subfamily Lutrinae of the family Mustelidae, which also includes weasels, polecats, badgers, and others.
ounce: An avoirdupois ounce, weighing 1/16 of an avoirdupois pound, or 28.3495 grams.
outdo: To excel; go beyond in performance; surpass.
outgo: The act or process of going out.
ovary: A female reproductive organ, often paired, that produces ova and in mammals secretes the hormones estrogen and progesterone.
overt: Open and not concealed or secret.
ovoid: Something that is oval in shape.
owing: To be under an obligation to give something back to someone or to perform some action for someone.
oxide: A binary chemical compound of oxygen with another chemical element.
ozone: An allotrope of oxygen (symbol O₃) having three atoms in the molecule instead of the usual two; it is a blue gas, generated from oxygen by electrical discharge.
paddy: Rough or unhusked rice, either before it is milled or as a crop to be harvested.
pagan: A person not adhering to a main world religion; a follower of a pantheistic or nature-worshipping religion.
paint: A substance that is applied as a liquid or paste, and dries into a solid coating that protects or adds color/colour to an object or surface to which it has been applied.
palsy: Complete or partial muscle paralysis of a body part, often accompanied by a loss of feeling and uncontrolled body movements such as shaking.
panel: A (usually) rectangular section of a surface, or of a covering or of a wall, fence etc.
panic: Overpowering fright, often affecting groups of people or animals.
pansy: A cultivated flowering plant, derived by hybridization within species Viola tricolor.
papal: Having to do with the pope or the papacy.
paper: A sheet material used for writing on or printing on (or as a non-waterproof container), usually made by draining cellulose fibres from a suspension in water.
parer: A small, sharp knife used to remove a thin layer from the outside of something, such as fruit or vegetables.
parka: A long jacket with a hood which protects the wearer against rain and wind.
parry: A defensive or deflective action; an act of parrying.
party: A person or group of people constituting a particular side in a contract or legal action.
pasta: Dough made from wheat and water and sometimes mixed with egg and formed into various shapes; often sold in dried form and typically boiled for eating.
paste: A soft moist mixture, in particular:
pasty: (chiefly in the plural) A small item of clothing that conceals little more than the nipple of a woman's breast, primarily worn by female exotic dancers.
patch: A piece of cloth, or other suitable material, sewed or otherwise fixed upon a garment to repair or strengthen it, especially upon an old garment to cover a hole.
patio: A paved outside area, adjoining a house, used for dining or recreation.
patsy: A person who is taken advantage of, especially by being cheated or blamed for something.
patty: (US, Australia, New Zealand) A flattened portion of ground meat or a vegetarian equivalent, usually round but sometimes square in shape.
pause: A button whose functions are pausing and resuming something, such as a DVD player, a video game or a computer.
payee: One to whom money is paid.
payer: One who pays; specifically, the person by whom a bill or note has been, or should be, paid.
peace: A state of tranquility, quiet, and harmony; absence of violence. For instance, a state free from civil disturbance.
peach: A tree (Prunus persica), native to China and now widely cultivated throughout temperate regions, having pink flowers and edible fruit.
pearl: A shelly concretion, usually rounded, and having a brilliant luster, with varying tints, found in the mantle, or between the mantle and shell, of certain bivalve mollusks, especially in the pearl oysters and river mussels, and sometimes in certain univalves. It is usually due to a secretion of shelly substance around some irritating foreign particle. Its substance is the same as nacre, or mother-of-pearl. Round lustrous pearls are used in jewellery.
pecan: A deciduous tree, Carya illinoinensis, of the central and southern United States, having deeply furrowed bark, pinnately compound leaves, and edible nuts.
pedal: A lever operated by one's foot that is used to control or power a machine or mechanism, such as a bicycle or piano
pence: In the United Kingdom and Ireland, a copper coin worth 1/240 of a pound sterling or Irish pound before decimalisation. Abbreviation: d.
penne: A type of short, diagonally cut pasta.
penny: In the United Kingdom and Ireland, a copper coin worth 1/240 of a pound sterling or Irish pound before decimalisation. Abbreviation: d.
perch: Any of the three species of spiny-finned freshwater fish in the genus Perca.
peril: A situation of serious and immediate danger.
pesky: Annoying, troublesome, irritating (usually of an animal or child).
pesto: A sauce, especially for pasta, originating from the Genoa region in Italy, made from basil, garlic, pine nuts, olive oil and cheese (usually pecorino)
petal: One of the component parts of the corolla of a flower. It applies particularly, but not necessarily only, when the corolla consists of separate parts, that is when the petals are not connately fused. Petals are often brightly colored.
petty: (usually in the plural) A little schoolboy, either in grade or size.
phase: Any of the major appearances or aspects in which a thing of varying modes or conditions manifests itself to the eye or mind.
phone: A device for transmitting conversations and other sounds in real time across distances, now often a small portable unit also capable of running software etc.
phony: A person who assumes an identity or quality other than their own.
piano: A percussive keyboard musical instrument, usually ranging over seven octaves, with white and black colored keys, played by pressing these keys, causing hammers to strike strings
piece: A part of a larger whole, usually in such a form that it is able to be separated from other parts.
pilot: A person who steers a ship, a helmsman.
pinch: The action of squeezing a small amount of a person's skin and flesh, making it hurt.
piney: Of, pertaining to, or having many pines
pinky: Methylated spirits mixed with red wine or Condy's crystals.
pinto: A horse with a patchy coloration that includes white.
piper: A musician who plays a pipe.
pique: A feeling of enmity; ill-feeling, animosity; a transient feeling of wounded pride.
pitch: A sticky, gummy substance secreted by trees; sap.
pivot: A thing on which something turns; specifically a metal pointed pin or short shaft in machinery, such as the end of an axle or spindle.
pixel: One of the tiny dots that make up the representation of an image in a computer's memory.
pixie: (fantasy literature, fairy tales) A playful sprite or elflike or fairy-like creature.
pizza: A baked Italian dish of a thinly rolled bread dough crust typically topped before baking with tomato sauce, cheese and other ingredients such as meat, vegetables or fruit
place: (physical) An area; somewhere within an area.
plaid: A type of twilled woollen cloth, often with a tartan or chequered pattern.
plait: A flat fold; a doubling, as of cloth; a pleat.
plank: A long, broad and thick piece of timber, as opposed to a board which is less thick.
plant: A living organism of the kind exemplified by trees, shrubs, herbs, grasses, ferns, and mosses, typically growing in a permanent site, absorbing water and inorganic substances through its roots, and synthesizing nutrients in its leaves by photosynthesis using the green pigment chlorophyll.
plate: A slightly curved but almost flat dish from which food is served or eaten.
plead: To present (an argument or a plea), especially in a legal case.
pleat: A fold in the fabric of a garment, usually a skirt, as a part of the design of the garment, with the purpose of adding controlled fullness and freedom of movement, or taking up excess fabric. There are many types of pleats, differing in their construction and appearance.
plied: To bend; to fold; to mould; to adapt, to modify; to change (a person's) mind, to cause (a person) to submit.
plier: Pincers with parallel, flat, and typically serrated surfaces, used chiefly for gripping small objects or bending wire.
plumb: Measure (the depth of a body of water).
plume: A feather of a bird, especially a large or showy one used as a decoration.
plump: To grow plump; to swell out.
plunk: The dull thud of something landing on a surface.
plush: A textile fabric with a nap or shag on one side, longer and softer than the nap of velvet.
poise: A state of balance, equilibrium or stability.
poker: A metal rod, generally of wrought iron, for adjusting the burning logs or coals in a fire; a firestick.
polar: The line joining the points of contact of tangents drawn to meet a curve from a point called the pole of the line.
polka: A lively dance originating in Bohemia.
polyp: An abnormal growth protruding from a mucous membrane
poppy: Any plant of the genus Papaver or the family Papaveraceae, with crumpled, often red, petals and a milky juice having narcotic properties; especially the common poppy or corn poppy (Papaver rhoeas) which has orange-red flowers; the flower of such a plant.
porch: A covered and enclosed entrance to a building, whether taken from the interior, and forming a sort of vestibule within the main wall, or projecting without and with a separate roof.
poser: A particularly difficult question or puzzle.
posit: Something that is posited; a postulate.
posse: A group or company of people, originally especially one having hostile intent; a throng, a crowd.
pouch: A small bag usually closed with a drawstring.
pound: A unit of mass equal to 16 avoirdupois ounces (= 453.592 37 g). Today this value is the most common meaning of "pound" as a unit of weight.
pouty: Tending to pout; angry in a childish or cute way; showing mock anger.
power: Ability to do or undergo something.
prank: A practical joke or mischievous trick.
prawn: A crustacean of the suborder Dendrobranchiata.
preen: A forked tool used by clothiers for dressing cloth.
press: A device used to apply pressure to an item.
price: The cost required to gain possession of something.
prick: A small hole or perforation, caused by piercing.
pride: The quality or state of being proud; an unreasonable overestimation of one's own superiority in terms of talents, looks, wealth, importance etc., which manifests itself in lofty airs, distance, reserve and often contempt of others.
pried: To look where one is not welcome; to be nosy.
prime: The first hour of daylight; the first canonical hour.
primo: The principal part of a duet.
print: Books and other material created by printing presses, considered collectively or as a medium.
