prior: A high-ranking member of a monastery, usually lower in rank than an abbot.
prism: A polyhedron with parallel ends of the same size and shape, the other faces being parallelogram-shaped sides.
privy: An outdoor facility for urination and defecation, whether open (latrine) or enclosed (outhouse).
prize: That which is taken from another; something captured; a thing seized by force, stratagem, or superior power.
probe: Any of various medical instruments used to explore wounds, organs, etc.
prong: A thin, pointed, projecting part, as of an antler or a fork or similar tool. A tine.
proof: An effort, process, or operation designed to establish or discover a fact or truth; an act of testing; a test; a trial.
prose: Language, particularly written language, not intended as poetry.
proud: Feeling honoured (by something); feeling happy or satisfied about an event or fact; gratified.
proxy: An agent or substitute authorized to act for another person.
prude: A person who is or tries to be excessively proper, especially one who is easily offended by matters of a sexual nature.
psalm: A sacred song; a poetical composition for use in the praise or worship of God.
pubic: Of, or relating to the area of the body adjacent to the pubis or the pubes.
pudgy: Fat, overweight (pertaining particularly to children), plump; chubby.
puffy: Swollen or inflated in shape, as if filled with air; pillow-like.
pulse: A normally regular beat felt when arteries are depressed, caused by the pumping action of the heart.
punch: A hit or strike with one's fist.
pupil: A learner under the supervision of a teacher or professor.
puppy: A young dog, especially before sexual maturity (12-18 months)
puree: A food that has been ground or crushed into a thick liquid.
purer: Free of flaws or imperfections; unsullied.
purse: A small bag for carrying money.
pushy: Aggressively ambitious; overly assertive, bold or determined.
putty: A soft, malleable, grayish-yellow paste, made from whiting and raw linseed oil, that hardens after a few hours and is used chiefly for sealing glass panes in wooden window frames.
pygmy: (often capitalized) A member of one of various Ancient Equatorial African tribal peoples, notable for their very short stature.
quack: The sound made by a duck.
quail: To waste away; to fade, to wither
qualm: A feeling of apprehension, doubt, fear etc.
quark: In the Standard Model, an elementary subatomic particle that forms matter. They combine to form hadrons, such as protons and neutrons.
quart: A unit of liquid capacity equal to two pints; one-fourth (quarter) of a gallon. Equivalent to 1.136 liters in the UK and 0.946 liter (liquid quart) or 1.101 liters (dry quart) in the U.S.
quasi: Resembling or having a likeness to something
queen: A female monarch. Example: Queen Victoria.
queer: (sometimes derogatory) A person who is or appears homosexual, or who has homosexual qualities.
quell: Put an end to (a rebellion or other disorder), typically by the use of force.
query: A question, an inquiry (US), an enquiry (UK).
quest: A journey or effort in pursuit of a goal (often lengthy, ambitious, or fervent); a mission.
quick: Raw or sensitive flesh, especially that underneath finger and toe nails.
quill: The lower shaft of a feather, specifically the region lacking barbs.
quilt: A bed covering consisting of two layers of fabric stitched together, with insulation between, often having a decorative design.
quirk: An idiosyncrasy; a slight glitch, mannerism; something unusual about the manner or style of something or someone
quite: (heading) To the greatest extent or degree; completely, entirely.
quota: A proportional part or share; the share or proportion assigned to each in a division.
quote: A quotation; a statement attributed to a person.
rabbi: A Jewish scholar or teacher of halacha (Jewish law), capable of making halachic decisions.
rabid: A human or animal infected with rabies.
racer: Someone who takes part in a race.
radar: A method of detecting distant objects and determining their position, velocity, or other characteristics by analysis of sent radio waves (usually microwaves) reflected from their surfaces
radii: The long bone in the forearm, on the side of the thumb.
radio: The technology that allows for the transmission of sound or other signals by modulation of electromagnetic waves.
raise: An increase in wages or salary; a rise (UK).
rajah: A Hindu prince or ruler in India.
rally: A public gathering or mass meeting that is not mainly a protest and is organized to inspire enthusiasm for a cause.
ramen: Soup noodles of wheat, with various ingredients (Japanese style)
ranch: A large plot of land used for raising cattle, sheep or other livestock.
range: A line or series of mountains, buildings, etc.
rapid: (often in the plural) a rough section of a river or stream which is difficult to navigate due to the swift and turbulent motion of the water.
raspy: (of sound) Rough, raw, especially used to describe vocal quality.
ratio: A number representing a comparison between two named things.
raven: Any of several, generally large and lustrous black species of birds in the genus Corvus, especially the common raven, Corvus corax.
razor: A keen-edged knife of peculiar shape, used in shaving the hair from the face or other parts of the body.
reach: The act of stretching or extending; extension.
react: An emoji used to express a reaction to a post on social media.
realm: An abstract sphere of influence, real or imagined.
rearm: To replace or restore the weapons or arms of a previously defeated, or disarmed army, country, person or other body.
rebar: A steel reinforcing bar in a reinforced concrete structure.
rebel: A person who resists an established authority, often violently
rebus: A kind of word puzzle which uses pictures to represent words or parts of words.
rebut: To drive back or beat back; to repulse.
recap: A tire that has had new tread glued on.
recur: To have recourse (to) someone or something for assistance, support etc.
reedy: Full of, or edged with, reeds.
refit: The process of having something fitted again, repaired or restored.
rehab: Rehabilitation, especially to treat the use of recreational drugs.
relic: That which remains; that which is left after loss or decay; a remaining portion.
remit: Terms of reference; set of responsibilities; scope.
renew: To make (something) new again; to restore to freshness or original condition.
repel: To turn (someone) away from a privilege, right, job, etc.
reply: A written or spoken response; part of a conversation.
rerun: A television program shown after its initial presentation — particularly many weeks after its initial presentation; a repeat.
reset: To set back to the initial state.
resin: A viscous hydrocarbon secretion of many plants, particularly coniferous trees.
reuse: The act of salvaging or in some manner restoring a discarded item to yield something usable.
revel: An instance of merrymaking; a celebration.
revue: A form of theatrical entertainment in which recent events, popular fads, etc., are parodied. Any entertainment featuring skits, dances, and songs.
rider: One who rides, often on a horse or a motorcycle.
ridge: The back of any animal; especially the upper or projecting part of the back of a quadruped.
rifle: A shouldered firearm with a long, rifled barrel to improve range and accuracy.
rigid: A bicycle with no suspension system.
ripen: To grow ripe; to become mature (said of grain, fruit, flowers etc.)
riper: (of fruits, vegetables, seeds etc.) Ready for reaping or gathering; having attained perfection; mature
risen: To move, or appear to move, physically upwards relative to the ground.
rival: A competitor (person, team, company, etc.) with the same goal as another, or striving to attain the same thing. Defeating a rival may be a primary or necessary goal of a competitor.
river: A large and often winding stream which drains a land mass, carrying water down from higher areas to a lower point, oftentimes ending in another body of water, such as an ocean or in an inland sea.
rivet: A cylindrical mechanical fastener that attaches multiple parts together by fitting through a hole and deforming the head(s) at either end.
roach: Certain members of the fish family Cyprinidae, including:
roast: A cut of meat suited to roasting
robin: Any of various passerine birds (about 100 species) of the families Muscicapidae, Turdidae and Petroicidae (formerly Eopsaltriidae), typically with a red breast.
robot: A machine built to carry out some complex task or group of tasks by physically moving, especially one which can be programmed.
rodeo: A gathering of cattle to be branded.
roger: (radio telecommunications) Received (used in radio communications to acknowledge that a message has been received and understood)
rogue: A scoundrel, rascal or unprincipled, deceitful, and unreliable person.
roost: The place where a bird sleeps (usually its nest or a branch).
rotor: A rotating part of a mechanical device, for example in an electric motor, generator, alternator or pump.
rouge: Red or pink makeup to add colour to the cheeks; blusher.
rough: The unmowed part of a golf course.
round: So as to form a circle or trace a circular path, or approximation thereof.
route: A course or way which is traveled or passed.
rover: (usually in the plural) A randomly selected target.
royal: A royal person; a member of a royal family.
rugby: (usually uncountable) A form of football in which players can hold or kick an ovoid ball. The ball cannot be handled forwards and points are scored by touching the ball to the ground in the area past their opponent’s territory or kicking the ball between goalposts and over a crossbar.
ruler: A (usually rigid), flat, rectangular measuring or drawing device with graduations in units of measurement; a straightedge with markings.
rumba: A slow-paced Cuban partner dance in 4:4 time.
rumor: A statement or claim of questionable accuracy, from no known reliable source, usually spread by word of mouth.
rupee: The common name for the monetary currencies used in modern India, Mauritius, Nepal, Pakistan, the Seychelles, or Sri Lanka, often abbreviated ₨.
rural: A person from the countryside; a rustic.
safer: Not in danger; out of harm's reach.
saint: A person whom a church or another religious group has officially recognised as especially holy or godly; one eminent for piety and virtue.
salad: A food made primarily of a mixture of raw or cold ingredients, typically vegetables, usually served with a dressing such as vinegar or mayonnaise.
salon: A large room, especially one used to receive and entertain guests.
salsa: A spicy tomato sauce, often including onions and hot peppers.
salve: An ointment, cream, or balm with soothing, healing, or calming effects.
salvo: An exception; a reservation; an excuse.
saner: Being in a healthy condition; not deranged; thinking rationally.
sappy: Excessively sweet, emotional, nostalgic; cheesy; mushy. (British equivalent: soppy)
sassy: Bold and spirited, cheeky, impudent, saucy.
satin: A cloth woven from silk, nylon or polyester with a glossy surface and a dull back. (The same weaving technique applied to cotton produces cloth termed sateen).
satyr: A woodland creature with pointed ears, legs, and short horns of a goat and a fondness for unrestrained revelry.
sauce: A liquid (often thickened) condiment or accompaniment to food.
saucy: Similar to sauce; having the consistency or texture of sauce.
sauna: A room or a house designed for heat sessions.
saute: To cook (food) using a small amount of fat in an open pan over a relatively high heat, allowing the food to brown and form a crust stopping it from sticking to the pan as it cooks.
savor: The specific taste or smell of something.
scald: A burn, or injury to the skin or flesh, by hot liquid or steam.
scale: A ladder; a series of steps; a means of ascending.
scalp: The top of the head; the skull.
scamp: A rascal, swindler, or rogue; a ne'er-do-well.
scarf: A long, often knitted, garment worn around the neck.
scary: Causing or able to cause fright.
scene: The location of an event that attracts attention.
scion: A descendant, especially a first-generation descendant of a distinguished family.
scoff: Derision; ridicule; a derisive or mocking expression of scorn, contempt, or reproach.
scone: A small, rich, pastry or quick bread, sometimes baked on a griddle.
scoop: Any cup- or bowl-shaped tool, usually with a handle, used to lift and move loose or soft solid material.
scope: The breadth, depth or reach of a subject; a domain.
score: The total number of goals, points, runs, etc. earned by a participant in a game.
scour: The removal of sediment caused by swiftly moving water.
scout: A person sent out to gain and bring in tidings; especially, one employed in war to gain information about the enemy and ground.
scowl: The wrinkling of the brows or face in frowning; the expression of displeasure, sullenness, or discontent in the countenance; an angry frown.
scram: Leave in a hurry, go away.
scrap: A (small) piece; a fragment; a detached, incomplete portion.
scree: Loose stony debris on a slope.
screw: A device that has a helical function.
scrub: One who labors hard and lives meanly; a mean fellow.
scrum: A tightly-packed and disorderly crowd of people.
scuba: (underwater diving) An apparatus carried by a diver, which includes a tank holding compressed, filtered air and a regulator which delivers the air to the diver at ambient pressure which can be used underwater.
sedan: An enclosed windowed chair suitable for a single occupant, carried by at least two porters, in equal numbers in front and behind, using wooden rails that passed through metal brackets on the sides of the chair.
segue: An instance of segueing, a transition.
seize: To deliberately take hold of; to grab or capture.
semen: A sticky, milky fluid produced in male reproductive organs that contains the reproductive cells.
sense: Any of the manners by which living beings perceive the physical world: for humans sight, smell, hearing, touch, taste.
sepia: A dark brown pigment made from the secretions of the cuttlefish.
serif: A short line added to the end of a stroke in traditional typefaces, such as Times New Roman.
serum: The clear yellowish liquid obtained upon separating whole blood into its solid and liquid components after it has been allowed to clot.
serve: An act of putting the ball or shuttlecock in play in various games.
setup: Equipment designed for a particular purpose; an apparatus.
seven: The digit/figure 7 or an occurrence thereof.
sewer: A pipe or system of pipes used to remove human waste and to provide drainage.
shack: A crude, roughly built hut or cabin.
shade: Darkness where light, particularly sunlight, is blocked.
shaft: The entire body of a long weapon, such as an arrow.
shake: The act of shaking or being shaken; tremulous or back-and-forth motion.
shale: A shell or husk; a cod or pod.
shall: (modal, auxiliary verb, defective) Used before a verb to indicate the simple future tense in the first person singular or plural.
shalt: (modal, auxiliary verb, defective) Used before a verb to indicate the simple future tense in the first person singular or plural.
shame: Uncomfortable or painful feeling due to recognition or consciousness of one's own impropriety or dishonor or something being exposed that should have been kept private.
shank: The part of the leg between the knee and the ankle.
shape: The status or condition of something
shard: A piece of broken glass or pottery, especially one found in an archaeological dig.
share: A portion of something, especially a portion given or allotted to someone.
shark: A scaleless, predatory fish of the superorder Selachimorpha, with a cartilaginous skeleton and 5 to 7 gill slits on each side of its head.
sharp: The symbol ♯, placed after the name of a note in the key signature or before a note on the staff to indicate that the note is to be played a semitone higher.
shave: To make bald or shorter by using a tool such as a razor or pair of electric clippers to cut the hair close to the skin.
shawl: A square or rectangular piece of cloth worn as a covering for the head, neck, and shoulders, typically by women.
shear: A cutting tool similar to scissors, but often larger.
sheep: A woolly ruminant of the genus Ovis.
sheet: A thin bed cloth used as a covering for a mattress or as a layer over the sleeper.
sheik: The leader of an Arab village, family or small tribe.
shelf: A flat, rigid structure, fixed at right angles to a wall or forming a part of a cabinet, desk etc., and used to support, store or display objects.
shell: A hard external covering of an animal.
shied: To avoid due to timidness or caution.
shift: A modifier key whose main function is shifting between two or more functions of any of certain other keys (usually by pressing Shift and the other button simultaneously).
shine: Brightness from a source of light.
shire: Physical area administered by a sheriff.
shirk: One who shirks, who avoids a duty or responsibility.
shirt: An article of clothing that is worn on the upper part of the body, and often has sleeves, either long or short, that cover the arms.
shoal: A sandbank or sandbar creating a shallow.
shook: A set of pieces for making a cask or box, usually wood.
shoot: The emerging stem and embryonic leaves of a new plant.
shore: Land adjoining a non-flowing body of water, such as an ocean, lake or pond.
shorn: To cut, originally with a sword or other bladed weapon, now usually with shears, or as if using shears.
shout: A loud burst of voice or voices; a violent and sudden outcry, especially that of a multitude expressing joy, triumph, exultation, anger, or animated courage.
shown: To display, to have somebody see (something).
showy: Calling attention; flashy; standing out to the eye
shrew: Any of numerous small, mouselike, chiefly nocturnal, mammals of the family Soricidae (order Soricomorpha).
shrub: A woody plant smaller than a tree, and usually with several stems from the same base.
shrug: A lifting of the shoulders to signal indifference or a casual lack of knowledge.
shuck: The shell or husk, especially of grains (e.g. corn/maize) or nuts (e.g. walnuts).
shunt: An act of moving (suddenly), as due to a push or shove.
shush: To be quiet; to keep quiet.
sieve: A device with a mesh bottom to separate, in a granular material, larger particles from smaller ones, or to separate solid objects from a liquid.
sight: (in the singular) The ability to see.
sigma: The eighteenth letter of the Classical and Modern Greek alphabets, the twentieth letter of Old and Ancient.
silky: A seal which can magically transform into a human by shedding its skin.
since: From a specified time in the past.
sinew: A cord or tendon of the body.
singe: A burning of the surface; a slight burn.
siren: One of a group of nymphs who lured mariners to their death on the rocks.
sixth: (not used in the plural) The person or thing in the sixth position.
sixty: The cardinal number occurring after fifty-nine and before sixty-one, represented in Roman numerals as LX and in Arabic numerals as 60.
skate: A light boot, fitted with a blade, used for ice skating.
skiff: Term used in tea gardens and denotes the act of cutting/pruning the bushes as per the specific norms. Various types of skiff are used viz Light Skiff (LS), Medium Skiff (MS), Deep Skiff (DS) and Level Of Skiff (LOS).
skill: Capacity to do something well; technique, ability. Skills are usually acquired or learned, as opposed to abilities, which are often thought of as innate.
skimp: To mock, deride, scorn, scold, make fun of.
skirt: An article of clothing, usually worn by women and girls, that hangs from the waist and covers the lower part of the body.
skulk: Keep out of sight, typically with a sinister or cowardly motive.
skull: The main bones of the head considered as a unit; including the cranium, facial bones, and mandible.
skunk: Any of various small mammals, of the family Mephitidae, native to North and Central America, having a glossy black with a white coat and two musk glands at the base of the tail for emitting a noxious smell as a defensive measure.
slack: The part of anything that hangs loose, having no strain upon it.
slang: Language outside of conventional usage and in the informal register.
slash: A slashing action or motion, particularly:
slate: A fine-grained homogeneous sedimentary rock composed of clay or volcanic ash which has been metamorphosed so that it cleaves easily into thin layers.
sleep: To rest in a state of reduced consciousness.
sleet: Pellets of ice made of mostly frozen raindrops or refrozen melted snowflakes.
slept: To rest in a state of reduced consciousness.
slice: That which is thin and broad.
slick: A covering of liquid, particularly oil.
slide: An item of play equipment that children can climb up and then slide down again.
slime: Soft, moist earth or clay, having an adhesive quality; viscous mud; any substance of a dirty nature, that is moist, soft, and adhesive; bitumen; mud containing metallic ore, obtained in the preparatory dressing.
sling: An instrument for throwing stones or other missiles, consisting of a short strap with two strings fastened to its ends, or with a string fastened to one end and a light stick to the other.
sloop: A single-masted sailboat with only one headsail.
slope: An area of ground that tends evenly upward or downward.
slosh: A quantity of a liquid; more than a splash.
sloth: Laziness; slowness in the mindset; disinclination to action or labour.
slump: A heavy or helpless collapse; a slouching or drooping posture; a period of poor activity or performance, especially an extended period.
slung: To throw with a circular or arcing motion.
slurp: A loud sucking noise made in eating or drinking
smack: A distinct flavor, especially if slight.
small: Any part of something that is smaller or slimmer than the rest, now usually with anatomical reference to the back.
smash: The sound of a violent impact; a violent striking together.
smell: A sensation, pleasant or unpleasant, detected by inhaling air (or, the case of water-breathing animals, water) carrying airborne molecules of a substance.
smelt: Any small anadromous fish of the family Osmeridae, found in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans and in lakes in North America and northern part of Europe.
smile: A facial expression comprised by flexing the muscles of both ends of one's mouth, often showing the front teeth, without vocalisation, and in humans is a common involuntary or voluntary expression of happiness, pleasure, amusement or anxiety.
smirk: An uneven, often crooked smile that is insolent, self-satisfied or scornful
smith: A craftsperson who works metal into desired forms using a hammer and other tools, sometimes heating the metal to make it more workable, especially a blacksmith.
smock: A type of undergarment worn by women; a shift or slip.
smoke: The visible vapor/vapour, gases, and fine particles given off by burning or smoldering material.
snail: Any of very many animals (either hermaphroditic or nonhermaphroditic), of the class Gastropoda, having a coiled shell.
snake: A legless reptile of the sub-order Serpentes with a long, thin body and a fork-shaped tongue.
snare: A trap (especially one made from a loop of wire, string, or leather).
snarl: A knot or complication of hair, thread, or the like, difficult to disentangle.
sneak: One who sneaks; one who moves stealthily to acquire an item or information.
sneer: A facial expression where one slightly raises one corner of the upper lip, generally indicating scorn.
snide: An underhanded, tricky person given to sharp practise; a sharper; a cheat.
snipe: Any of various limicoline game birds of the genera Gallinago, Lymnocryptes and Coenocorypha in the family Scolopacidae, having a long, slender, nearly straight beak.
snore: The act of snoring, and the noise produced.
snort: The sound made by exhaling or inhaling roughly through the nose.
snout: The long, projecting nose, mouth, and jaw of a beast, as of pigs.
snowy: Marked by snow, characterized by snow.
snuck: To creep or go stealthily; to come or go while trying to avoid detection, as a person who does not wish to be seen.
snuff: Finely ground or pulverized tobacco intended for use by being sniffed or snorted into the nose.
sober: (often with up) To make or become sober.
soggy: Soaked with moisture or other liquid.
solar: Of or pertaining to the sun; proceeding from the sun
solid: A substance in the fundamental state of matter that retains its size and shape without need of a container (as opposed to a liquid or gas).
solve: (chiefly law enforcement) A solution; an explanation.
sooty: To blacken or make dirty with soot.
sorry: The act of saying sorry; an apology.
south: One of the four major compass points, specifically 180°, directed toward the South Pole, and conventionally downwards on a map, abbreviated as S.
sower: A person, machine, or device that scatters seed over the earth for the purpose of growth.
spade: A garden tool with a handle and a flat blade for digging. Not to be confused with a shovel which is used for moving earth or other materials.
spank: An instance of spanking, separately or part of a multiple blows-beating; a smack, swat, or slap.
spare: The act of sparing; moderation; restraint.
spark: A small particle of glowing matter, either molten or on fire.
spasm: A sudden, involuntary contraction of a muscle, a group of muscles, or a hollow organ.
spawn: To produce or deposit (eggs) in water.
speak: A low class bar, a speakeasy.
spear: A long stick with a sharp tip used as a weapon for throwing or thrusting, or anything used to make a thrusting motion.
speck: A tiny spot, especially of dirt etc.
speed: The state of moving quickly or the capacity for rapid motion; rapidity.
spell: Words or a formula supposed to have magical powers.
spelt: To read (something) as though letter by letter; to peruse slowly or with effort.
spend: Amount of money spent (during a period); expenditure.
sperm: The reproductive cell or gamete of the male; a spermatozoon.
spice: Aromatic or pungent plant matter (usually dried) used to season or flavour food.
spicy: Of, pertaining to, or containing spice.
spiel: A lengthy and extravagant speech or argument usually intended to persuade.
spike: In a violin-family instrument, the carved wooden plug which sits in the bottom block of the instrument.
spill: A mess of something that has been dropped.
spilt: To drop something so that it spreads out or makes a mess; to accidentally pour.
spine: The series of bones situated at the back from the head to the pelvis of a person, or from the head to the tail of an animal; backbone, vertebral column.
spiny: Full of or covered with prickles.
spire: The stalk or stem of a plant.
spite: Ill will or hatred toward another, accompanied with the desire to irritate, annoy, or thwart; a want to disturb or put out another; mild malice
splat: The narrow wooden centre piece of a chair back.
spoil: (Also in plural: spoils) Plunder taken from an enemy or victim.
spoke: A support structure that connects the axle or the hub of a wheel to the rim.
spoof: An act of deception; a hoax; a joking prank.
spool: A reel; a device around which thread, wire or cable is wound, especially a cylinder or spindle.
spoon: An implement for eating or serving; a scooped utensil whose long handle is straight, in contrast to a ladle.
spore: A reproductive particle, usually a single cell, released by a fungus, alga, or plant that may germinate into another.
sport: Any activity that uses physical exertion or skills competitively under a set of rules that is not based on aesthetics.
spout: A tube or lip through which liquid or steam is poured or discharged.
spray: A fine, gentle, dispersed mist of liquid.
spree: A merry frolic; especially, a drinking frolic.
sprig: A small shoot or twig of a tree or other plant; a spray.
spurn: An act of spurning; a scornful rejection.
spurt: A brief gush, as of liquid spurting from an orifice or a cut/wound.
squad: A group of people organized for some common purpose, usually of about ten members.
squib: A small firework that is intended to spew sparks rather than explode.
staff: (plural staffs or staves) A long, straight, thick wooden rod or stick, especially one used to assist in walking.
staid: Not capricious or impulsive; sedate, serious, sober.
stair: A single step in a staircase.
stake: A piece of wood or other material, usually long and slender, pointed at one end so as to be easily driven into the ground as a marker or a support or stay.
stale: Something stale; a loaf of bread or the like that is no longer fresh.
stalk: The stem or main axis of a plant, which supports the seed-carrying parts.
stall: A compartment for a single animal in a stable or cattle shed.
stamp: An act of stamping the foot, paw or hoof.
stank: To have a strong bad smell.
stash: A collection, sometimes hidden; a reserve.
state: A condition; a set of circumstances applying at any given time.
stave: One of a number of narrow strips of wood, or narrow iron plates, placed edge to edge to form the sides, covering, or lining of a vessel or structure; especially, one of the strips which form the sides of a cask, a pail, etc.
stead: A place, or spot, in general.
steak: Beefsteak, a slice of beef, broiled or cut for broiling.
steam: The vapor formed when water changes from liquid phase to gas phase.
steed: A stallion, especially in the sense of mount.
steel: An artificial metal produced from iron, harder and more elastic than elemental iron; used figuratively as a symbol of hardness.
steep: The steep side of a mountain etc.; a slope or acclivity.
steer: A suggestion about a course of action.
stein: A beer mug, usually made of ceramic or glass.
stern: Having a hardness and severity of nature or manner.
stick: An elongated piece of wood or similar material, typically put to some use, for example as a wand or baton.
stiff: An average person, usually male, of no particular distinction, skill, or education, often a working stiff or lucky stiff.
still: A period of calm or silence.
stilt: Either of two poles with footrests that allow someone to stand or walk above the ground; used mostly by entertainers.
sting: A bump left on the skin after having been stung.
stint: A period of time spent doing or being something; a spell.
stoic: Proponent of stoicism, a school of thought, from in 300 B.C.E. up to about the time of Marcus Aurelius, who holds that by cultivating an understanding of the logos, or natural law, one can be free of suffering.
stole: To take illegally, or without the owner's permission, something owned by someone else.
stomp: A deliberate heavy footfall; a stamp.
stone: A hard earthen substance that can form large rocks.
stood: (heading) To position or be positioned physically.
stool: A seat, especially for one person and without armrests.
stoop: The staircase and landing or porch leading to the entrance of a residence.
store: A place where items may be accumulated or routinely kept.
stork: A large wading bird with long legs and a long beak of the family Ciconiidae.
storm: Any disturbed state of the atmosphere, especially as affecting the earth's surface, and strongly implying destructive or unpleasant weather.
story: A sequence of real or fictional events; or, an account of such a sequence.
stout: A dark and strong malt brew made with toasted grain.
stove: A heater, a closed apparatus to burn fuel for the warming of a room.
strap: A long, narrow, pliable strip of leather, cloth, or the like.
straw: A dried stalk of a cereal plant.
stray: Any domestic animal that has no enclosure, or its proper place and company, and wanders at large, or is lost; an estray.
strip: A long, thin piece of land; any long, thin area.
stuck: To become or remain attached; to adhere.
study: (usually academic) To review materials already learned in order to make sure one does not forget them, usually in preparation for an examination.
stuff: Miscellaneous items or objects; (with possessive) personal effects.
stump: The remains of something that has been cut off; especially the remains of a tree, the remains of a limb.
stung: To hurt, usually by introducing poison or a sharp point, or both.
stunk: To have a strong bad smell.
stunt: A daring or dangerous feat, often involving the display of gymnastic skills.
style: Senses relating to a thin, pointed object.
sugar: Sucrose in the form of small crystals, obtained from sugar cane or sugar beet and used to sweeten food and drink.
suing: To file a legal action against someone, generally a non-criminal action.
suite: A retinue or company of attendants, as of a distinguished personage
sulky: A low two-wheeled cart, used in harness racing.
sumac: Any of various shrubs or small trees of the genus Rhus and other genera in Anacardiaceae, particularly the elm-leaved sumac, Sicilian sumac, or tanner's sumac (Rhus coriaria).
surer: Physically secure and certain, non-failing, reliable.
surge: A sudden transient rush, flood or increase.
sushi: A Japanese dish made of small portions of sticky white rice flavored with vinegar, usually wrapped in seaweed and filled or topped with fish, vegetables or meat.
swami: (used as a title) A Hindu ascetic or religious teacher.
swamp: A piece of wet, spongy land; low ground saturated with water; soft, wet ground which may have a growth of certain kinds of trees, but is unfit for agricultural or pastoral purposes.
swarm: A large number of insects, especially when in motion or (for bees) migrating to a new colony.
swash: The water that washes up on shore after an incoming wave has broken
swath: The track cut out by a scythe in mowing.
swear: To take an oath, to promise.
sweat: Fluid that exits the body through pores in the skin usually due to physical stress and/or high temperature for the purpose of regulating body temperature and removing certain compounds from the circulation.
sweet: The basic taste sensation induced by sugar.
swell: To become bigger, especially due to being engorged.
swept: To clean (a surface) by means of a stroking motion of a broom or brush.
swill: (collective) A mixture of solid and liquid food scraps fed to pigs etc; especially kitchen waste for this purpose.
swing: The manner in which something is swung.
swish: A short rustling, hissing or whistling sound, often made by friction.
swoop: An instance, or the act of suddenly plunging downward.
sword: A long-bladed weapon with a hilt, and usually a pommel and cross-guard, which is designed to stab, slash, and/or hack.
swore: To take an oath, to promise.
sworn: To take an oath, to promise.
swung: To rotate about an off-centre fixed point.
synod: An ecclesiastic council or meeting to consult on church matters.
syrup: Any thick liquid that has a high sugar content and which is added to or poured over food as a flavouring.
tabby: A kind of waved silk, usually called watered silk, manufactured like taffeta, but thicker and stronger. The watering is given to it by calendering.
table: Furniture with a top surface to accommodate a variety of uses.
taboo: An inhibition or ban that results from social custom or emotional aversion.
tacit: Expressed in silence; implied, but not made explicit; silent.
taffy: A soft, chewy candy made from boiled molasses or brown sugar.
taint: A contamination, decay or putrefaction, especially in food
taken: To get into one's hands, possession or control, with or without force.
talon: A sharp, hooked claw of a bird of prey or other predatory animal.
tamer: Not or no longer wild; domesticated
tango: A Standard ballroom dance in 4/4 time; or a social dance, the Argentine tango.
taper: A slender wax candle; a small lighted wax candle
tapir: Any one of the species of large odd-toed ungulates of the taxonomic family Tapiridae with a long prehensile upper lip, of which all four surviving species are in genus Tapirus.
tardy: A piece of paper given to students who are late to class.
tarot: (singular or plural) A card game played in various different variations.
taste: One of the sensations produced by the tongue in response to certain chemicals; the quality of giving this sensation.
tasty: Having a pleasant or satisfying flavor; delicious.
taunt: A scornful or mocking remark; a jeer or mockery
tawny: A light brown to brownish orange colour.
teach: To show (someone) the way; to guide, conduct; to point, indicate.
teary: Of a person, having eyes filled with tears; inclined to cry.
teeth: The ability to be enforced, or to be enforced to any useful effect.
tenet: An opinion, belief, or principle that is held as absolute truth by someone or especially an organization.
tenor: A musical range or section higher than bass and lower than alto.
tense: (grammar) Any of the forms of a verb which distinguish when an action or state of being occurs or exists.
tenth: The person or thing coming next after the ninth in a series; that which is in the tenth position.
terra: (astrogeology) A rough upland or mountainous region of the Moon with a relatively high albedo.
terse: (by extension) Of speech or style: brief, concise, to the point.
thank: An expression of appreciation; a thought.
their: A form of the possessive case of plural they used as an attributive adjective, before a noun.
theme: A subject of a talk or an artistic piece; a topic.
these: The thing, item, etc. being indicated.
theta: The eighth letter of the Modern Greek alphabet, ninth in Old Greek: Θ, θ.
thick: The thickest, or most active or intense, part of something.
thief: One who carries out a theft.
thigh: The upper leg of a human, between the hip and the knee.
thing: That which is considered to exist as a separate entity, object, quality or concept.
think: An act of thinking; consideration (of something).
third: The person or thing in the third position.
thorn: A sharp protective spine of a plant.
those: (demonstrative) The thing, person, idea, quality, event, action or time indicated or understood from context, especially if more remote geographically, temporally or mentally than one designated as "this", or if expressing distinction.
thrum: A thrumming sound; a hum or vibration.
thumb: The short thick digit of the hand that for humans has the most mobility and can be made to oppose (moved to touch) all of the other fingers.
thump: A blow that produces a muffled sound.
thyme: Any plant of the labiate genus Thymus, such as the garden thyme, Thymus vulgaris, a warm, pungent aromatic, that is much used to give a relish to seasoning and soups.
tibia: The inner and usually the larger of the two bones of the leg or hind limb below the knee, the shinbone
tiger: Panthera tigris, a large predatory mammal of the cat family, indigenous to Asia.
tight: Fixed, fastened, or closed firmly; hard to move, undo, or open.
tipsy: Slightly drunk, fuddled, staggering, foolish as a result of drinking alcoholic beverages
titan: Something or someone of very large stature, greatness, or godliness.
title: A prefix (honorific) or suffix (post-nominal) added to a person's name to signify either veneration, official position or a professional or academic qualification. See also
toddy: A drink made from alcoholic liquor mixed with sugar, spice and hot water.
token: Something serving as an expression of something else.
tonal: Of or relating to tones or tonality.
tonga: A light, two-wheeled, horse-drawn carriage used for transportation in India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh.
tonic: A substance with medicinal properties intended to restore or invigorate.
tooth: A hard, calcareous structure present in the mouth of many vertebrate animals, generally used for eating.
topaz: A silicate mineral of aluminium and fluorine, usually tinted by impurities.
topic: Subject; theme; a category or general area of interest.
torch: A stick with a flame on one end, used chiefly as a light source; a similarly shaped implement with a replaceable supply of flammable material.
torso: The main part of the (human) body that extends from the neck to the groin, excluding the head and limbs.
torus: A topological space which is a product of two circles.
total: An amount obtained by the addition of smaller amounts.
totem: Any natural object or living creature that serves as an emblem of a tribe, clan or family.
touch: Come into or be in contact with.
tough: A person who obtains things by force; a thug or bully.
towel: A cloth used for wiping, especially one used for drying anything wet, as a person after a bath.
tower: A very tall iron-framed structure, usually painted red and white, on which microwave, radio, satellite, or other communication antennas are installed; mast.
toxic: Having a chemical nature that is harmful to health or lethal if consumed or otherwise entering into the body in sufficient quantities.
toxin: A toxic or poisonous substance produced by the biological processes of biological organisms.
track: A mark left by something that has passed along.
trade: Buying and selling of goods and services on a market.
trail: The track or indication marking the route followed by something that has passed, such as the footprints of animal on land or the contrail of an airplane in the sky.
trait: An identifying characteristic, habit or trend.
tramp: (sometimes derogatory) A homeless person; a vagabond.
trash: Useless things to be discarded; rubbish; refuse.
trawl: A net or dragnet used for trawling.
tread: To step or walk (on or over something); to trample.
treat: An entertainment, outing, food, drink, or other indulgence provided by someone for the enjoyment of others.
trend: An inclination in a particular direction.
trial: An opportunity to test something out; a test.
tribe: A socially, ethnically, or politically cohesive group of people.
trice: To pull, to pull out or away, to pull sharply.
trick: Something designed to fool or swindle.
tried: Tested, hence, proven to be firm or reliable.
tripe: The lining of the large stomach of ruminating animals, when prepared for food.
trite: Often in reference to a word or phrase: used so many times that it is commonplace, or no longer interesting or effective; worn out, hackneyed.
troll: A supernatural being of varying size, now especially a grotesque humanoid creature living in caves or hills or under bridges.
troop: (collective) A collection of people; a number; a multitude (in general).
trope: Something recurring across a genre or type of art or literature, such as the ‘mad scientist’ of horror movies or the use of the phrase ‘once upon a time’ as an introduction to fairy tales; a motif.
trout: Any of several species of fish in Salmonidae, closely related to salmon, and distinguished by spawning more than once.
trove: A treasure trove; a collection of treasure.
truce: A period of time in which no fighting takes place due to an agreement between the opposed parties
truck: A small wheel or roller, specifically the wheel of a gun carriage.
truer: (of a statement) Conforming to the actual state of reality or fact; factually correct.
truly: (manner) In accordance with the facts; truthfully, accurately.
trump: The suit, in a game of cards, that outranks all others.
truss: A bandage and belt used to hold a hernia in place.
trust: Confidence in or reliance on some person or quality.
truth: True facts, genuine depiction or statements of reality.
tryst: A prearranged meeting or assignation, now especially between lovers to meet at a specific place and time.
tubal: Of or pertaining to a tube, especially an anatomical one
tuber: A fleshy, thickened underground stem of a plant, usually containing stored starch, for example a potato or arrowroot.
tulip: A type of flowering plant, genus Tulipa.
tulle: A kind of silk lace or light netting, used for clothing, veils, etc.
tumor: An abnormal growth; differential diagnosis includes abscess, metaplasia, and neoplasia.
tunic: A garment worn over the torso, with or without sleeves, and of various lengths reaching from the hips to the ankles.
tutor: One who teaches another (usually called a student, learner, or tutee) in a one-on-one or small-group interaction.
twang: The sharp, quick sound of a vibrating tight string, for example, of a bow or a musical instrument.
tweak: A sharp pinch or jerk; a twist or twitch.
tweed: A coarse woolen fabric used for clothing.
tweet: The sound of a bird; any short high-pitched sound or whistle.
twirl: A movement where a person spins round elegantly; a pirouette.
tying: To twist (a string, rope, or the like) around itself securely.
udder: An organ formed of the mammary glands of female quadruped mammals, particularly ruminants such as cattle, goats, sheep and deer.
ulcer: An open sore of the skin, eyes or mucous membrane, often caused by an initial abrasion and generally maintained by an inflammation and/or an infection.
umbra: The fully shaded inner region of a shadow cast by an opaque object.
uncle: The brother or brother-in-law of one’s parent.
undid: To reverse the effects of an action.
undue: Excessive; going beyond that what is natural or sufficient.
unfed: A mosquito that has not had a blood meal.
unfit: To make unfit; to render unsuitable, spoil, disqualify.
unify: Cause to become one; make into a unit; consolidate; merge; combine.
union: The act of uniting or joining two or more things into one.
unite: A British gold coin worth 20 shillings, first produced during the reign of King James I, and bearing a legend indicating the king's intention of uniting the kingdoms of England and Scotland.
unity: Oneness; the state or fact of being one undivided entity.
untie: To loosen, as something interlaced or knotted; to disengage the parts of.
until: Up to the time of (something happening).
unwed: One who is not married; a bachelor or a spinster.
unzip: To open something using a zipper.
upper: A stimulant, such as amphetamine, that increases energy and decreases appetite.
urine: Liquid waste consisting of water, salts and urea, which is made in the kidneys, stored in the bladder, then released through the urethra.
usage: The manner or the amount of using; use.
usher: A person, in a church, cinema etc., who escorts people to their seats.
usual: The typical state of something, or something that is typical.
usurp: To seize power from another, usually by illegitimate means.
utile: A theoretical unit of measure of utility, for indicating a supposed quantity of satisfaction derived from an economic transaction.
valet: A man's personal male attendant, responsible for his clothes and appearance.
value: The quality (positive or negative) that renders something desirable or valuable.
valve: A device that controls the flow of a gas or fluid through a pipe.
vapid: Offering nothing that is stimulating or challenging.
vapor: Cloudy diffused matter such as mist, steam or fumes suspended in the air.
vault: An arched masonry structure supporting and forming a ceiling, whether freestanding or forming part of a larger building.
vaunt: A boast; an instance of vaunting.
vegan: A person who does not eat, drink or otherwise consume any animal products
venom: A poison carried by an animal, usually injected into an enemy or prey by biting or stinging.
venue: A theater, auditorium, arena, or other area designated for sporting or entertainment events.
verge: A rod or staff of office, e.g. of a verger.
verse: A poetic form with regular meter and a fixed rhyme scheme.
verso: The back side of a flat object which is to be examined visually, as for reading, such as a sheet, leaf, coin or medal;
verve: Excitement of imagination such as that which animates a poet, artist, or musician, in composing or performing
vicar: In the Church of England, the priest of a parish, receiving a salary or stipend but not tithes.
vigil: An instance of keeping awake during normal sleeping hours, especially to keep watch or pray.
vigor: Active strength or force of body or mind; capacity for exertion, physically, intellectually, or morally; energy.
villa: (plural "villas") A house, often larger and more expensive than average, in the countryside or on the coast, often used as a retreat.
vinyl: The univalent radical CH2=CH−, derived from ethylene.
viola: A stringed instrument of the violin family, somewhat larger than a violin, played under the chin, and having a deeper tone.
viper: A venomous snake in the family Viperidae.
viral: A video, image or text spread by "word of mouth" on the internet or by e-mail for humorous, political or marketing purposes.
virus: A submicroscopic, non-cellular structure consisting of a core of DNA or RNA surrounded by a protein coat, that requires a living host cell to replicate, and often causes disease in the host organism.
visor: A part of a helmet, arranged so as to lift or open, and so show the face. The openings for seeing and breathing are generally in it.
vista: A distant view or prospect, especially one seen through some opening, avenue or passage.
vital: Relating to, or characteristic of life.
vocal: A vocal sound; specifically, a purely vocal element of speech, unmodified except by resonance; a vowel or a diphthong; a tonic element; a tonic; distinguished from a subvocal, and a nonvocal
vodka: A clear distilled alcoholic liquor made from grain mash.
voice: Sound uttered by the mouth, especially by human beings in speech or song; sound thus uttered considered as possessing some special quality or character
voila: Lo, there it is; see here; ta-da; presto; behold!
vomit: The regurgitated former contents of a stomach; vomitus.
vowel: A sound produced by the vocal cords with relatively little restriction of the oral cavity, forming the prominent sound of a syllable.
vying: To fight for superiority; to contend; to compete eagerly so as to gain something.
wager: Something deposited, laid, or hazarded on the event of a contest or an unsettled question; a bet; a stake; a pledge.
wagon: A four-wheeled cart for hauling loads.
waist: The part of the body between the pelvis and the stomach.
waive: To relinquish (a right etc.); to give up claim to; to forego.
warty: Of the nature of or resembling a wart; characterized by warts.
waste: Excess of material, useless by-products or damaged, unsaleable products; garbage; rubbish.
water: A substance (of molecular formula H₂O) found at room temperature and pressure as a clear liquid; it is present naturally as rain, and found in rivers, lakes and seas; its solid form is ice and its gaseous form is steam.
waver: An act of wavering, vacillating, etc.
weary: To make or to become weary.
weave: A type or way of weaving.
wedge: One of the simple machines; a piece of material, such as metal or wood, thick at one edge and tapered to a thin edge at the other for insertion in a narrow crevice, used for splitting, tightening, securing, or levering.
weigh: To determine the weight of an object.
welch: A person who defaults on an obligation, especially a small one.
welsh: To swindle someone by not paying a debt, especially a gambling debt.
whale: Any of several species of large sea mammals of the infraorder Cetacea.
wharf: A man-made landing place for ships on a shore or river bank.
wheat: Any of several cereal grains, of the genus Triticum, that yields flour as used in bakery.
wheel: A circular device capable of rotating on its axis, facilitating movement or transportation or performing labour in machines.
whelp: A young offspring of a canid (ursid, felid, pinniped), especially of a dog or a wolf, the young of a bear or similar mammal (lion, tiger, seal); a pup, wolf cub.
where: The place in which something happens.
which: (interrogative) What one or ones (of those mentioned or implied).
whiff: A waft; a brief, gentle breeze; a light gust of air
while: An uncertain duration of time, a period of time.
whine: A long-drawn, high-pitched complaining cry or sound
whiny: Whining; tending to whine or complain.
white: The color/colour of snow or milk; the colour of light containing equal amounts of all visible wavelengths.
whole: Something complete, without any parts missing.
whoop: A loud, eager cry, usually of joy.
whose: (interrogative) That or those of whom or belonging to whom.
wider: Having a large physical extent from side to side.
widow: A woman whose spouse has died (and who has not remarried); feminine of widower.
wield: To command, rule over; to possess or own.
wight: A living creature, especially a human being.
wimpy: Having the characteristics of a wimp; feeble, indecisive, cowardly.
wince: A sudden movement or gesture of shrinking away.
winch: A machine consisting of a drum on an axle, a friction brake or ratchet and pawl, and a crank handle or prime mover (often an electric or hydraulic motor), with or without gearing, to give increased mechanical advantage when hauling on a rope or cable.
wiser: Showing good judgement or the benefit of experience.
wispy: Consisting of or resembling a wisp; like a slender, flexible strand or bundle.
witch: A person who practices witchcraft; a woman or man who practices witchcraft.
woken: (often followed by up) To stop sleeping.
woody: An early station wagon or estate car in which the rear portion of the car's bodywork is made of wood, often associated with Southern California surfing culture.
wooer: To seek the favor, affection, or love of, especially with a view to marriage.
wooly: A sweater or similar garment made of wool.
wordy: Using an excessive number of words.
world: (with "the") Human collective existence; existence in general.
would: Something that would happen, or would be the case, under different circumstances; a potentiality.
wound: An injury, such as a cut, stab, or tear, to a (usually external) part of the body.
woven: To form something by passing lengths or strands of material over and under one another.
wrack: Vengeance; revenge; persecution; punishment; consequence; trouble.
wreak: To cause something harmful; to afflict; to inflict; to harm or injury; to let out something harmful; .
wreck: Something or someone that has been ruined.
wrest: The act of wresting; a wrench or twist; distortion.
wring: A powerful squeezing or twisting action.
wrist: The complex joint between forearm bones, carpus, and metacarpals where the hand is attached to the arm; the carpus in a narrow sense.
write: The act or style of writing.
wrong: Something that is immoral or not good.
wrote: To form letters, words or symbols on a surface in order to communicate.
wrung: To squeeze or twist (something) tightly so that liquid is forced out. See also wring out.
yacht: A slick and light ship for making pleasure trips or racing on water, having sails but often motor-powered. At times used as a residence offshore on a dock.
yearn: To long, have a strong desire (for something).
yeast: An often humid, yellowish froth produced by fermenting malt worts, and used to brew beer, leaven bread, and also used in certain medicines.
yield: To pay, give in payment; repay, recompense; reward; requite.
young: People who are young; young people, collectively; youth.
youth: The quality or state of being young.
zebra: Any of three species of genus Equus: E. grevyi, E. quagga, or E. zebra, all with black and white stripes and native to Africa.
zesty: Having a strong, pleasant, and somewhat spicy flavor.
